summary: In Earth's future, a global crop blight and second Dust Bowl are slowly rendering the planet uninhabitable. Professor Brand (Michael Caine), a brilliant NASA physicist, is working on plans to save mankind by transporting Earth's population to a new home via a wormhole. But first, Brand must send former NASA pilot Cooper (Matthew McConaughey) and a team of researchers through the wormhole and across the galaxy to find out which of three planets could be mankind's new home.

reviews.content: A nice movie with very good visuals, which reaches its greatest when defining a world in decadence with extreme realism, but its lowest when recurring to storytelling mechanisms that have become a bit too obvious for audiences familiarised with time-travel sci-fi. In general, I recommend it. The best: the way Nolan depicts a decadent humanity without either the use of guilt and blame characteristic of climate change-based accounts nor the exaggerated thunders of catastrophic events movies; just a slow, unavoidable path into decadence, where civilization has to fold on itself –or not.
one of the best movie i ever seen

Interstellar is a fantastic film that combines beautiful imagery with creative and intelligent ideas/concepts. The connection between a father and his children pulls at the heartstrings and grounds the movie in reality.

An All Time Classic. Phenomenally edited and incredibly imaginative cinematography with a epic story to back it up. the music is very good but I wouldn't call it catchy, though it is very memorable. The pacing is a perfect slow burn that suits the complicated story perfectly. The acting is phenomenal as well. though it takes some time to warm up to everyone, once the slow burn builds momentum the acting builds right along with it. This is a film everyone should see once. The less you know about the story the better.

In November of 2014 I was 8 years old; my parents were never particularly cinephiles. As long as I have lived with my parents, they pressed quality cinema and literature upon me. My Mother can't recall what possessed her to take me to the movies on that unusually warm November night. It wasn't often that my parents would let me spend time in front of screens or eating junk food and candy, this was a rare treat. I was wide eyed and happy, oblivious to what I was about to witness. Often in this age of the internet we forget that our access to knowledge and news was constricted. Being an elementary school student without access to any computers or phones I had no knowledge of what I didn't see in advertisements, hear in school or learn from my parents. One of my main memories from that first viewing was confusion and drowsiness. A run time of nearly 3 hours and I had stayed up way past my bedtime. But what that night did was it laid the foundation. I have never written a movie review before; for a while I have considered diving into scriptwriting and involving myself further in cinema, but I couldn't find the right channel. I recently realized that reviews, even if they remain unread, are a great way to channel my passion. I chose to review this film for a single reason: it's stunning. Christopher Nolan is perhaps one of the greatest filmmakers ever. Interstellar's incredible cinematography and attention to detail with the addition of Hans Zimmer's greatest soundtrack demands the viewer's full attention. I look forward to the day that Interstellar will be passed in excellence by the next masterpiece. However, for now Cooper's journey to find home is the greatest movie of all time.

Um dos melhores filmes de ficção científica já feitos, ao mesmo tempo um dos melhores épicos. Apesar do roteiro perder força no terceiro ato, e as soluções propostas por ele não serem condizentes 100% com o que foi proposto e desenvolvido ao longo da trama ("o amor supera tudo" não é o melhor argumento p pôr na conclusão de um filme que foi todo racional e cientificamente embasado até o terceiro ato), é sem dúvida uma das maiores obras primas do nosso século. Tecnicamente é impecável, e o casting foi um dos melhores da história do cinema. Dá p perceber claramente que todos envolvidos no projeto estavam completamente entregues a ele e acima de tudo amam o cinema, e o resultado não podia ser diferente. Nesses casos o amor realmente provoca feitos monumentais. Como já pontuado, não é perfeito, mas não posso deixar de considerar como um dos filmes que mais me marcaram, consequentemente, um dos meus favoritos.

I've had a strange relationship with this movie over the years.

I didn't have the chance to see it in movie theaters when it came out, but caught up with it on streaming release & immediately liked it except for some sections of jarring dialogue & unnecessary exposition - which admittedly took up only about 2% of the movie, but had an outsized effect on me because - well - I expected and desperately wanted perfection.

When I viewed it the second time, I was even more angry with the Nolan team for the few mistakes of the film. After all, this was the movie I'd been waiting for someone to make for years. Why couldn't it have been perfect?

I saw it a third time. Why, you may ask? Because despite the errors the story haunted me. And I had to admit to myself that it was beautifully executed & acted, with possibly the best soundtrack in movie history. It was on this viewing that I managed to just let go & relax into the film.

I was stunned.

How could I have missed this masterpiece? A complex, tightly knit, scientifically accurate story (Kip Thorne won the Nobel prize in physics later in 2017) that seemed to have been plucked right out of some fictional ether, instead of painstakingly worked out around a table in a story room. Some stories are like that; they feel more real than real, like they have always existed and were waiting for a hand to snatch them and gift them to us.

It occurred to me too that some works of art, like this film, can have a sort of 'emergence' - that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts, and that it may well take time for a culture to come to recognize its true greatness. I see now that the flaws of this film are very small and don't matter at all. The movie's greatness transcends its own mistakes.

I don't know if any movie will ever be made to match Interstellar. As sad as that makes me, I'm happy enough to just keep watching and re-watching. If you haven't seen it yet - I envy you.

I have just seen Interstellar, the latest offering from director Christopher Nolan. The film is a sci-fi epic about a group of astronauts who venture through a wormhole in search of a new home for humanity. The film boasts a stellar cast including Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, and Jessica Chastain, and an incredible visual experience.

The plot of Interstellar is well thought out and beautifully executed. It is a story about hope and humanity's drive to survive, and it is told in a way that is both scientifically accurate and emotionally impactful. The themes of love and sacrifice are explored in a profound and meaningful way, making the film a true work of art.

The acting in Interstellar is top-notch. McConaughey delivers a standout performance as the lead, capturing the right amount of emotion and depth to make the audience connect with his character. Hathaway and Chastain both deliver strong performances as well, adding depth and nuance to the film.

The direction and cinematography in Interstellar are exceptional. Nolan is known for his visual storytelling, and this film is no exception. The film's visuals are breathtaking, with incredible landscapes and space scenes that will leave you in awe. The score by Hans Zimmer is equally impressive, elevating the film to another level and providing a haunting and memorable soundscape.

The special effects in Interstellar are absolutely stunning. From the massive black holes to the beautiful celestial bodies, every aspect of the film's visual design is meticulously crafted to deliver a truly immersive experience. The film's production design is similarly impressive, with a believable and well-realized futuristic world.

The editing and pace of Interstellar are masterful, with a well-crafted rhythm that keeps the film moving forward and engaging the audience at all times. The dialogue is smart, and thought-provoking, and adds to the film's overall impact.

In conclusion, Interstellar is a triumph of filmmaking. It is a film that will make you feel, think, and question. It is a beautiful and profound work of art that will stay with you long after the credits have rolled. If you are a fan of sci-fi or Christopher Nolan, this film is a must-see.

Christopher Nolan's futuristic trek into the stars is a visually stunning and heartbreakingly real film that also happens to be the director's best entry to date. Matthew McConaughey plays Cooper, a former pilot turned corn farmer who stumbles onto a NASA plan to search for a new home. Earth has been turned into a ball of dust by climate change and one thing is clear as crops continue dying out: Humanity can't sustain itself here. Cooper teams up with Professor Brand (played by Michael Caine) and his daughter (played by Anne Hathaway) to traverse through a recently (and mysteriously) opened wormhole through which other options for planetary habitation exist. What results is two stories told simultaneously: Cooper's daughter Murph (played by Jessica Chastain) is determined to help her father's mission by computing equations with Professor Brand on Earth as well as the space odyssey itself. Chastain's devotion to her work is a thin mask worn to protect herself from further hurt at her father leaving her during her childhood. Cooper's journey only takes him so long, but due to the changing weight of gravity in their various stops his time moves differently than those still on Earth, allowing Murph to grow from a child to an adult while Cooper is gone. In space, Cooper and crew are to investigate three potential new homes after successfully traveling through a wormhole (the images of which were impressively rendered before our first real-life visual of a black hole) with varying degrees of success. In the end Nolan manages to tie the terrestrial, metaphysical, and intergalactic altogether in a way that can only be described as poetic. Excellent writing, acting, and story pacing culminate in one of the greatest sci-fi epics of the past decade and, perhaps, of all time.

Very cerebral, I was interested in the setup of a father trying to save Earth but as the movie progressed, I felt it got bogged down in its own mythology.  Beside the fact, that the film moved at a glacial pace (after watching it twice), I'm still unclear on its concept of time, gravity and space.  Visually stunning with sufficient emotional depth from the first-rate cast and crew, I am somewhat disappointed with the outcome.  Was it a cautionary tale of what happens when humanity doesn't take care of its resources?  Is it just a tale of heroic efforts at great personal sacrifice?  Perhaps, both but again I'm not sure.  Watch at your own risk.

Interstellar is by far my most favorite film I have watched. A little bit of action, a little bit of science, a little bit of seriousness, and a little bit of laughter. It brings together the human instinct of survival and the inevitable issues of the future to create a story of both time, gravity, and joy. By far the best acting performance of the movie is Matthew McConaughey as Cooper. Everything from the emotions he feels for his family as well as the little quirks of jokes and interactions with his other travelers and artificial intelligence is what truly makes the movie stand out. I also appreciate the acting prowess from Chastain and Hathaway, who both put together endearing characters that shined individually and supplementally to McConaughey's Cooper. In terms of storytelling, Nolan doesn't disappoint. The way he ties everything together is perfect, as well as his choices in cinematography. The scene where Michael Caine has a voice over monologue is a perfect example of how great Nolan is at directing. In addition, the accuracy of the science behind the entire plot of the story just adds to how real the movie is and how it reflects to the audience. Also, Hans Zimmer is HIM.

Christopher Nolan's "Interstellar" gives a space thriller take on the relationship between a man and his daughter. Matthew McConnaghae's performance displays the tragic yet heartwarming arc of a man who has to see the world he knows fall to pieces, then sacrifice his own life to save it. Throughout the time he is away saving the world, the movie follows an intriguing story line where he continues to face deep hardships and sacrifices. The screenplay of the movie travels through some of the most exotic locations on earth, creating an exhilarating viewer experience. The director, Christopher Nolan, also uses a different use of sound than what is traditional to most films. He creates suspense by using screechy and uneasy audio during scenes that are supposed to make you uncomfortable, doing this creates a sense of suspense for the audience. The movie also explores complex ideas regarding our universe which leave you thinking about the movie well after watching it. The depths the movie dives to in existentialism leave the viewer questioning their own surroundings, as well as the world beyond their own reach. In the film Christopher Nolan's greatest concept explored throughout the movie is the concept of time and how it relates to the world and universe around us. During the movie he plays with the concept of how time can move differently for different people and locations, this ends up creating a dramatic twist in the end by reuniting the characters. Christopher Nolan's style of movie directing is often seen as unconventional which makes it so his film doesn't stick well with all viewers. The reason this works for him is because he is able to reach a specific audience with his films and create them in a way to a virtual masterpiece for its intended audience. I would highly recommend this creative masterpiece to any one who wishes to explore movies with deep perspectives. This is the movie that is able to express Christopher Nolan's genius perspectives and ideas. The film is able to leave a lasting impression on you, which makes you want to keep rewatching to keep gaining understanding of its excellence. This movie goes down in my top 10 movies ever along with a few other Christopher Nolan films. I would especially recommend this to people like myself who appreciate a movie's ability to make you think about and explore complex concepts. I would give this movie a rating of 8.9 out of 10.

Arguably Nolan's best film since The Dark Knight Rises. Not only Nolan's undisputed and undeniable best film he's ever made, but also a strong contender for best film of ALL TIME. Stanley Kubrick opened the floodgates with 2001: A Space Odyssey. Now? Nolan did what Kubrick couldn't. Not only does Interstellar answer the question that Space Odyssey simply wasn't clear enough to answer, it's simply better in every way. Nolan creates a real life, living, breathing, living intergalactic world. Nolan's work is so immaculate and precise that he actually helped make a scientific discovery. Every single detail is explained in detail so you actually know what's going on in Interstellar. When this film says, "Mankind was born on Earth, never meant to die here," what it really means is that filmmaking was born on Earth and is not meant to stagnate here. Nolan is a filmmaker who makes movies ethereal. The Waste Land is representative of Hollywood and its failed, unoriginal ideas, while the film's intergalactic discoveries represent how Nolan rebooted the film industry. While the spaceship takes off with Matthew McConaughey as the pilot, Hollywood takes off with Christopher Nolan piloting it.

Interstellar was one of the movies I didn't care about this year. One of my friends is a real Nolan fan and he promoted it but every time he put a trailer in our group chat I didn't watch it and when he had news I didn't bother to read it. Hell, I didn't even know Matt Damon was in it, I didn't even know Matthew was starring. I actually only remembered that this movie existed because my group of friends decided to go and I was like "hell, let's try it". That gives you some information about what I knew about the movie beforehand.

What I got was one of, if not the best movie I have ever seen. It was so beautiful that sometimes I find myself thinking "damn, is this real life or cgi?", and that's coming from a computer gamer who is known for putting up with graphics. Visually, I can say without a doubt that it's the best ever made, you can't find a better looking one. That said, the story was a bit of a cliché. I figured out pretty quickly that the wormhole was going to be important and that the "ghost" was the father since the Morse code for the word "stay" was also pretty obvious. That said, it was a pretty damn good story, and even a gritty one has its twists, but it wasn't too distracting. So story wise I would rate it 7/10.

Now the most important part, or at least for me: the feeling after leaving the cinema. It got me thinking. The movie sparked your imagination and showed us some possibilities of what we could do. One of my first thoughts when I left the theater was: This is going to inspire people the way Star Wars did back then. It's the kind of movie that you'll still think about and remember in a few months, and that's why it's such a good movie: It's funny on a really high level without being an action movie or a comedy. fires up your brain.

All in all, and I know this will be pretty unpopular with a lot of people, I think this movie should be IMDB #1 with a score of 93/100, just above The Shawshank Redemption. This is mostly to do with 2001 being so high on the list and in my opinion 2001 should be compared to that movie and not the other way around. It should be about this movie. It has every single aspect of a good movie: Great cast, near perfect acting, drama, humor, action, suspense, visuals so beautiful they make you wonder if it's cgi or not, no major scientific flaws, and let's not forget innovation ( the way these robots were made, brilliant!) it was quite original, it had breathtaking music, it was immersive and even hard, it was long, it didn't feel long. This 2001 movie looked like a b-movie.

So yeah, I'm not a professional reviewer, but since I was so blown away by this movie, I needed to get it out there

Simply was a transcendental experience watching it on the IMAX screen! I was gasping in wonder one minute, while sobbing the next. It made me encounter so many different emotions in such a short span of time that I really didn't expect from watching a sci-fi masterpiece tackling complicated theories about quantum physics. The cast was beyond amazing and the cinematography and special effects were all mind-blowing. And that score! Hans Zimmer is indeed a GOD. That soundtrack complimented the plot so well and elevated it during all the key moments.

This is an immersive watch. Its quite intriguing, although a bit bleak, philosophically speaking. It, unsurprisingly, features good CGI and its quite gripping at times, although I felt frustrated by the quite frequent whispery/mumbled dialogue, this makes it hard to follow whats being said at times. I suppose the film is about hope, though I'd also say its about determination and isolation. 

The dialogue is a little cheesy at times, with one line I remember being "love is the only thing capable of transcending time and space'. A more notable quote, I thought, was 'out survival instinct is our greatest source of inspiration'. Suffice to say, this is not a light watch(!), thus its a bit hard to follow fully but I'd be lying if I said it doesn't have anything going for it. There are some plot twists and near the end I did feel a bit let down a bit, in as much as I can't say I felt what happened was entirely believable? also it didn't surprise me this is a Christopher Nolan film, given one of the aspects featured in the film which clearly harked back to Inception.

I thought the cast gave relatively decent performances and its certainly a thought provoking film - its somewhat memorable too. I'd say, in my mind, its more of what I'd call a 'deep film' than an 'epic', although it certainly has an epic running time of just shy of 3 hours long (2h49 to the end of the credits). If this really interests you, then its probably worth seeing but if your not interested in the sci-fi aspects of this, then it'll likely seem a bit too long winded and lose your interest, so I'm 50/50 about recommending it but hopefully my review has given you an idea if this is for you or not.

It was... fine. I love the sci-fi on display. It's hard, and crunchy, and the visuals and the scope of the concept make this really fun. The story however is a bit sloppy. The core of the story is good: space adventuring and weird "all in the name of love" time-travel melding.

The problem is that it's awful serious about it, to the point that it feels a bit masturbatory. By the 32nd time you hear "Do not go gentle," you want to scream at the film and just say OKAY WE GET IT. You can tell they had these huge concepts and a lot to say, but even with the ultra extended runtime, they just couldn't figure out how to tighten it all together into a good, cohesive whole. As a result, it feels like they said everything they wanted to say, but didn't really get it all out, leaving either a lot of confusion or a lot of doubt in its wake.

It's certainly not a bad film though. And if this inspires people to enjoy sci-fi, who am I to besmirch it? I was just hoping for something more, and given that I had zero expectations and was not spoiled at all going into this film, that's a bit disappointing. It was a fun ride, and a neat journey, but I felt somehow unfulfilled by the end.

The final hour of this film contains some of the best filmmaking  I've ever seen. McConaughey and Jessica Chastain give two of the best performances of their careers. They are by far the standout characters in the film. This is a huge plus because the story revolves around their relationship, which is well-developed throughout the movie. This film takes risks and leaps for abstract concepts/themes, and it basically nails them all.

It's impossible to overlook Hans Zimmer's score. What he composed for this picture is some of the most beautiful music I've ever heard, and the way it complements Nolan's scenes is some of the most unrivaled movie magic I've ever experienced.

The only flaws I found in this film were a few brief sequences on Earth during the climax and a few cheesy lines of dialogue sprinkled throughout the movie. The dialogue is mostly flawless, with the exception of Brand's speech about love, which is a little heavy-handed. Despite these minor flaws, I believe the greatness of this movie is so powerful that it still qualifies for a perfect rating.

Although Interstellar isn't my favorite Nolan film, it is unquestionably one of his masterpieces. I can understand why this might be someone's favorite of his works. When the credits start rolling, the themes hit you so hard that you are left speechless.
Hits all the notes when it comes to photography, visuals, score, writing, and acting. Absolutely amazing movie and there's no reason not to watch it.

Interstellar (A+)

What a journey this movie puts you through. Achieving high concepts with grace and having great cinematography along the way this movie truly transports you to an alternate future/reality that becomes more and more engrossing as you watch. I have seen this plenty of times and with every re-watch the message seems more clear and I pick out new things I learned. Christopher Nolan truly had a visionary mind when crafting this film and to see it come to life on screen is one reason that I truly appreciate moviegoing to the extent I do.

The movie is really well done in no small part to the grounded characters. Matthew McConaughey holds a lot of weight in the role as this is undoubtedly his best acting of his career to date. He shows the emotion effortlessly through his facial expressions and delivery of dialogue. Anne Hathaway isn't usually my favorite actress but she does surprisingly well in this role for this film. Also Matt Damon has a smaller role in this film but his time is truly felt as he is probably the story arch and character I remember the most when I think on this film. This is not to mention the rest of the star studded cast of Jessica Chastain, Micheal Caine and even a young Timothée Chalamet.

The real meat and potatoes behind this film however is found through the ambitious story. It is the backdrop to an epic and ever evolving landscape that I think is beautifully and expertly crafted. People who have problems with this film boil it down to it not making to much logical sense and being overly ambitious. I would have maybe sided with them more upon my first watch but with every subsequent viewing I pick apart different aspects of the film and for within the film it actually works all relatively soundly. Now sure you have to suspend some disbelief that the characters keep narrowly escaping their ultimate demise but the whole message of this film of love and fate helps to show that maybe their "luck" is just this worlds way of having fate play its part in the perfect manner it was intended.

With a powerful soundtrack by Hans Zimmer, amazing visual effects, and impressive overall spectacle this movie comes in as a homerun in my books. Up there with some of Nolan's best work this movie only gets better for me as I continue to come back to it. I am also a person who likes thinking outside the box and considering new ideas so that has to be noted in playing a factor into my love for this film.

The ending is a great Nolan ending, one that worked very well. It explains everything that feels impossible or unknown like a slap in the viewers face. Its a complex plot, but it works.

Time travel or Relative time is also really nicely explored making science freaks like me really happy.

The "bad" part is that Interestellar uses our physics current limitation (e.g the undefined, still not discovered intern of a blackhole or how its created) to create a vast almost supernatural experience.
Even if science cannot accurately "unprove" its story it doesn't feel like it is really possible.

This is genuinely one of the most amazing movies I have every watched. And I don't say this lightly. The total ratings this movie received on rotten tomatoes honestly hurts me, this movie easily belongs in the high 90's %. Can't believe movies like Mission Impossible received higher rankings than this. Nothing against Mission Impossible, but Interstellar is EASILY better than MI. 

Everything about this movie works. So fucking well. The story. The acting. The characters. The cinematography. The balance of action and drama. The balance of real science and science fiction. The black hole. The soundtrack. Don't even get me started on the soundtrack. 

Needless to say, the acting was phenomenal. Matthew McConaughey absolutely killed it in his role. I also loved Jessica Chastain's performance. Although her role was relatively minor, Mackenzie Foy also did an excellent job of playing young Murph. All the other supporting actors were really great too (Matt Damon, Michael Caine, Anne Hathaway, etc), however the three I listed I believe just stood out. 

The story was beautiful. And it combined all of the elements of what makes a great story so perfectly. The excitement of discovery and space exploration. The anxiety of the outcome of the human race. The frustration of betrayal. The mystery of the ghost. The heartbreak of a loved one leaving. But also the love of a bond that transcends space and time. 

And all the things this story makes you feel, are super amplified by one hell of a soundtrack. Hans Zimmer is guilty for this soundtrack. Now one thing I know when it comes to Hans Zimmer, is that if he has written a soundtrack for a film, that film is gonna have one damn amazing soundtrack. But interstellar was even amazing for him. Just that next level. Each sound, makes you feel so much, and perfectly captures the thoughts and feelings of each and every scene.

Amazing cinematography also. The landscape shots of Earth are stunning, and the same goes for the camera angles of space. The scenes are always really well set. The camera shots capture the beauty of Earth, the other planets and space. 

And I am crazy for gargantua, the black hole featured in this film. So much real research and scientific data was used, and so much effort was put in to generate the animation of gargantua. It is as beautiful as it is terrifying to look at, and I love how this movie went to the effort to ensure the black hole was as accurate as possible, despite this largely being a science fiction film.

I don't think I appreciated the dystopian world that Christopher Nolan had created the first (and only other) time I viewed this movie. In addition, I also found the acting to be really well-done, notably the scene when Cooper (McConaughey) is leaving his daughter, Murphy (Mackenzie Foy), and when he's seeing his grandchild for the first time (over a transmission recording). Movies that concern massive consequences for humanity are a good place to start with me — it's a reason why Children of Men is my favorite movie — and you don't get that much more consequential than the survival of the species. In this world, the planet is beyond repair and 21st Century conquistadores must venture beyond new horizons (to put it lightly) to find humanity a new home. I love — and have come to expect — difficult scientific concepts boiled down to simple, laymen's explanations; a corroborating visual makes that all the better. We get it here, paper and pencil and all. There are legitimate action thrills, whether they be from monstrous tidal waves or a traumatized astronaut (Damon). Maybe the tesseract climax was a little too convenient and weird and… confusing(?) but it didn't take away as much from the plot for me, but I see how it could be a huge letdown for others. The recurring theme is delightful and excellent to use as background music for studying/working. The RT is at (72/86) right now and had you asked me before re-watching it, I probably would've assumed I'd be closer to the critics, turns out I'm much more with the "audience," my people, and our simplistic scientific explainers. I was hard on Nolan for Tenet, which I think is underwhelming at best, stupid and pretentious at worst, but Interstellar, on the other hand, is something you should revisit, if the summer blockbusters this year aren't delivering.

Interstellar is not a typical sci-fi save the day run of the mill film, and the heart of this film carries a message I think everyone can learn from. Interstellar takes the tropes of space travel and grounds them into reality time is everything and exploring space has the ultimate cost of time. Time is the most important resource in our lives. Yet there is something ever more powerful than even time itself that this movie presents. Our emotions and our connections with others are ever present. We are humans and we seek to connect no matter the cost, and despite being millions of light years away and time pressing forward in an endless march our connections will grow, break, and form anew. Because as cheesy as it may sound, despite the nihilistic nature of our existence our bonds and connections with others can be just as effective and quantifiable as any part of known physics

One of my absolute all-time favorites.  I agree wholeheartedly with several of the more educated reviews on RT.  The negative reviews are from people who probably try to one-up everyone else's story at a party.  There is something for everyone in this movie.  The acting, the cast, the plot, the cinematography, the emotional ride... everything about it is spectacular and I feel this may only be appreciated decades from now, as we continue to learn more about the universe/space etc.  I've seen a number of reviews that say that Interstellar is "over ambitious" but I couldn't disagree more.  It's one of the most ambitious movies ever directed and not only did they pull it off, they nailed it.  When it comes to the expansion of our universe, I don't think anything is farfetched, but Interstellar made me feel as if I was journeying into our future and watching a real-life space exploration take place, rather than a science fiction flick.  I will be watching this with my grandchildren one day!  Absolute 10/10, must see.

Christopher Nolan's film-Interstellar; a movie about humanity fleeing an Earth, on the verge of destruction-to find another planet to call home, may on paper...sound like another tried and tested sci-fi formula that would just be lost amongst the plethora of similar movies through the ages. However to say it is not so, is a gross understatement. Coming fresh off the success of his Dark Knight series, Christopher Nolan breathed fresh air into the sci fi genre with gorgeous spectacles, amazing cgi-coupled with his innate attention to detail that most filmmakers can only dream of. Some scenes were planned out in such an artistic way that they required little to no dialogue to convey the atmosphere of the scene. The planets, the technology-all seemed so realistic that it resembled a real life documentary, more than it did, a sci fi movie. Visuals are the core of the film but what drives the movie...or rather is the backbone of the entire thing is the soundtrack. Hans Zimmer, the Mozart of our generation once again,delivered a soundtrack that you could play on repeat in your very home and feel like you were a lone astronaut-swimming through the vast, black ocean outside our planet; with little to no hope for rescue, yet daring to imagine a beautiful salvation. This soundtrack has to say the least, achieved the same legendary status as the scores of Inception and Matrix, and shall be remembered for years to come. The story can be a bit confusing for those who want to kick back with a bag of popcorn and not spend their brain cells on a movie-but for those who wonder...who look up at the night sky and reach out for it...for them, this is a love letter for all space-enthusiasts and even the ones who know nothing beyond the solar system, shall enjoy it for what it is. Huge praise has to be given to the academy award winning/nominees actor Matthew McConaughey, Annie Hathaway, Jessica Chastain and Michael Caine. A film is only as good as its actors/actresses and for a masterpiece like Interstellar...it is suffice to say that the cast delivered. At the end I would like to say that this movie deserves...nay, needs to be spotlighted on the hall of fame as the film that proved that sci fi movies, aren't just for the nerds or geeks. A masterful filmaker can spin a web so finely, that it can seduce it's audience's attention and interest in a matter of seconds. And that, in a nutshell-is Interstellar.
One of my favorite movies of all time.

While "Interstellar" never entirely commits to the idea of a non-rational, uncanny world, it nevertheless has a mystical strain, one that's unusually pronounced for a director whose storytelling has the right-brained sensibility of an engineer, logician, or accountant. There's a ghost in this film, writing out messages to the living in dust. Characters strain to interpret distant radio messages as if they were ancient texts written in a dead language, and stare through red-rimmed eyes at video messages sent years ago, by people on the other side of the cosmos. "Interstellar" features a family haunted by the memory of a dead mother and then an absent father; a woman haunted by the memory of a missing father, and another woman who's separated from her own dad (and mentor), and driven to reunite with a lover separated from her by so many millions of miles that he might as well be dead.

Interstellar is a stunning example of mind-blowing sci-fi and a story that reflects humanity all tied into one neat package. At its heart, it really is a film about humanity, which is why I believe it resonates so well with its audience. I would give the film 9.5 out of 10 stars, because of its emotional depths and fascinating plot.
	The film begins by introducing us to the premise: in a dystopian future, humanity doesn't seem like it will survive for much longer on Earth. But more than that, it introduces us to (Joseph) Cooper, Murphy, and the rest of Cooper's family. You really get the sense that Cooper is a family man, and the bond between Cooper and Murphy is all laid out right in the beginning. And interestingly, the idea of Murphy's ghost is introduced here, which pays off much later in the film. 
	But when NASA calls, Cooper answers, launching us from the exposition into the film. Humanity has to uproot itself for survival, and what NASA wants Cooper to do is scout these other planets to see how fit they would be for survival. But Murphy doesn't want Cooper to go. Murphy's child actor does a great job with, and the emotional plot thread of being away from family begins here. The mission seems to go well at first, until a giant wave on an ocean-planet causes the death of a crewmate, and Cooper and Amelia Brand find that time has been dilated for them, and over twenty years has passed. What follows is where I really became emotionally invested, as Cooper finds recordings of messages from his children, now grown. Especially heartbreaking is the message from Murphy, now the same age as Cooper, saying, "now would be a really good time for you to come back." These moments would not work as well without Matthew McConaughey, who shakes and sobs in a way that feels utterly, captivatingly real. There's no single man-tear or delicate crying, this movie just makes it feel ugly and raw and human. 
	But the plot continues nonetheless. Cooper, Amelia, and Romilly go find Matt Damon's Mann, who laughs or sobs into Cooper's chest upon being awakened. That moment continues on for long enough to be uncomfortable, but is also what I like about it. Again, it just feels raw, not manufactured, which makes the moment resonate. Meanwhile, back on Earth, Murphy finds out that uprooting all of human civilization was never the plan, leaving most of humanity to die. She sends a message to the crew, to which Cooper announces he's going back to Earth. However, Mann reveals his true colors and sabotages Cooper (which I didn't expect as much as I really should've. I think watching The Martian before this skewed my thoughts on Matt Damon's character). This betrayal, again, is ugly but it never descends to cartoon villainy in my opinion because the film gives Mann motivation that makes you understand his actions, and sympathize with him. Nonetheless, Mann ends up dying, and it is just Cooper and Amelia trying to reach the other planet.
	Until it is just Amelia trying to reach the other planet, as Cooper ejects himself from the spacecraft to ensure Amelia can make it. In the most mind-boggling section of the movie, Cooper finds himself in a physical dimension that represents time. Made of bookcases, he glances through to see moments from his past and realizes that he can send messages—that he was Murphy's ghost all along. McConaughey gives another incredible performance here, rummaging through the bookshelves with sheer desperation, but also the realization that love will save all of humanity. Along with the physical time dimension aspect, it should be cheesy, but it's not. It works thanks to the stakes and the performances from the actors, and somehow, the climax feels just right. In a movie that centers Cooper and Murphy's father-daughter relationship as the main emotional thread, of course it all gets tied together and that relationship ends up saving humanity. This solution feels earned, all the way through.
	The conclusion to the film is sweet, showing humanity's survival, but Murphy has also grown old. The way Cooper cups her frail face, almost reverently, really kicks you in the gut. Cooper has saved his daughter, but at the cost of not being able to see her for the majority of her life, up until death. Finally, the movie ends on Cooper seeking out Amelia, and while it's unknown how that search turns out, the movie ends on that note of hope for the future. I enjoyed overall how bittersweet everything seemed to be, one last sendoff that was, like the rest of the film, absolutely human.

Christopher Nolen rides again with this massive scale sci-if journey story that braids cutting edge special effects, amazing performances and a supremely inventive story together to make what is sure to be one of the year's landmark films. The movie stars Matthew McConaughey as Cooper, a NASA astronaut forced to become a farmer in a world where earth's natural resources have dwindled down to nearly nil. As Cooper struggles to raise his children during what seems to be humanity's final throws, a team of scientists, headed by Nolen favorites Michael Caine, Anne Hathaway and David Gyasi, put together a daring plan to save humanity by searching for new inhabitable world's beyond our galaxy and require Cooper's skill to get them there.

I really dug the hell out of this movie. As a fan of space travel myself, I really have to say that they did a great job at capturing a lot of the real math and science theory behind space travel, relativity theory and even some of the more edgy ideas about the characteristics of black holes. It's clear that the Nolen brothers Christopher and Jonathen did their homework while writing this script. The performances are also quite good here and Jessica Chastaine, who plays Cooper's grownup daughter, is especially impressive. These things married with the IMAX scope and the bigger than life special effects make this movie an absolute joy to watch. Everything is not all aces here as the film is not without its faults. Perhaps the thing I had the most problem with was the film's third act. The movie spends a long time setting up a very real and for the most part, a scientifically sound universe that is on par with 2001: A Space Odyssey and even to some degree it makes fun of a tropish, nonsensical and dumb way that the story could end as if to say, "we're smarter than that, c'mon, what do you take us for?" only to give in and end it that way anyway. At first I was ok with it but the more that I look at the film, the less the ending makes sense and the more the film starts to eat itself which was needless to say, really disappointing.

Overall, I still liked the movie and despite my issues with the third act, I recommend it, and if you can, spring for the IMAX because the scope and scale of the visuals are ridiculous! No television could ever do it justice. This film is for sure to be in talks to win an award of some kind for special effects in the coming months and it's well deserved. If you love liked Gravity or 2001: A Space Odyssey or Apollo 13, you are sure to like this too. Interstellar gets a 3.5...out of 5.

As someone who has always had interest in outer space as a kid, I always wanted a movie about space where unnecessary alien invasions and their civilisations are not shown. And with Interstellar my that dream definitely did come true, though not as much as I was hoping it to be. There are many things in this movie that I didn't understand, and the cosmic concepts are definitely not one of them.
So first of all, this movie is taking place in a dystopian future. If I didn't know better I'd think that it's happening in an alternate reality. There was no mention of this being in the future at any point in the beginning. The only way to know about things was by people's talking, and I will explain later why it was a terrible decision.
So everything about humanity is on a path of destruction and thus they choose to find a wormhole through which they can go to another planet and live over there, which is something I completely agree with. I'm the kind of a person who completely supports humanity to settle in space and letting nature and wildlife live on Earth in peace. But why are they going as far as another planet? Can't they just live on Mars or Titan? They looked way safer than the water planet they went to. The excuse that Mars and Titan don't have oxygen won't work because neither did this planet. And it was shown very well in the fight scene.
Speaking of the fight scene, it was completely unnecessary. This is a movie about interdimensional space travel. No one is interested in petty conflicts. Already we are tensed about the crew not making it back to Earth and Cooper's daughter ageing and never getting to know whether her father is alright or not. I was feeling very bad for her. She didn't even take the opportunity to say goodbye to her father and now she has to regret about this for her whole life. On the other hand Cooper is also very tensed about not getting to see her daughter before she grows old and dies.
My favourite part in the entire movie was when he reached the fifth dimension. He could see his daughter from the day he left her. While floating behind a bookshelf he tried his best to make her understand that he wanted to see her. And finally after long he decided to use the Morse code from the watch to make her understand. I was really empathising with him. I was feeling how I'd behave in a situation like this, where someone I have to contact does not even know Morse code and there is no way I could talk to them. Finally in the end we get to see the awesome world that the scientists make, where the gravity gets inverted and people can live in a much bigger place. It was a terrific idea. I wasn't even expecting the movie to end like that.
And now like I said, I'll talk about the audio quality. The voice is so low and the score is so high it's very hard to listen to all the exposition that is given. Normally I'd not have any problem with that, but out of almost 3 hours of this movie, 2 hours is just talking, talking and more talking. I'm not able to read subtitles very fast so I couldn't keep track of what was going on. In fact, when TARS was speaking I didn't even know it was him. I used to think it's someone else in the background on whom the camera has not been shown. Since the volume was so low, it wasn't even possible to understand that these were different voices. And speaking of TARS, he was the most forgettable character in the movie. To write this review I had to watch Honest Trailers to remember everything, and then I remembered that TARS was even a thing.
Interstellar is a masterpiece we can only expect Christopher Nolan to make. If anyone else had made a movie about outer space, they'd have definitely added aliens, like fishes on the new planet, or some rabbits hiding in their burrows. But I'm really glad that didn't happen, because that would have meant humanity didn't learn from its past mistakes and are choosing to start life on someone else's land. If it weren't for the long low volume talking and the forced exposition meant for uninformed audience, it'd have easily been my favourite Nolan movie.

It's truly an incredible film. Some parts are too long and unimportant, but for most of the time I was completely caught up in the story. With its beautiful message, mind-blowing ideas and great acting, Interstellar is a masterpiece of science fiction.

Interstellar visual is an art worthy of all awards and accolades. Many shots from this film want to see in the form of a picture at home.

Watching Interstellar, you start to believe in the true power of cinema. Because of the drama, because of the direction, because of the composing skills of Hans Zimmer. And you start to believe in the genius of Christopher Nolan.

The story has a very personal, intimate connotation. The relationship between father and children. A father who will have to save humanity, in the truest sense of these words. The cold, boundless space echoes with the pain of a long separation between native people.

One of my first impressions after watching Interstellar is, that it is completely different yet familiar movie in relation with Christopher Nolan's style. It has the director's signature mark on some points, like the plot twists, the mystery and/or the confusing theme subject (at times). Regardless, I have to say that I don't really know how to feel about this film. Sure, the visual effects are gorgeous and stunning, and the movie is well based on real science. But, talking about the story, I didn't really like it. I feel like the movie started off in an excellent way, I really liked the story at first. But, for me, the part where Doctor Mann is introduced and we learn some sketchy things, is where the film changed the direction completely on to a path that I don't really love. It starts to get a little too complictaed for me. All the stuff with the dimensions, the ending, the timeline... too confusing. It's a shame really, because I was feeling that Interstellar was going to be epic from beginning to end. It's also a bit over-long and the acting is just good, nothing special. Still, it is not a rotten movie, and I guess each person has it's own interpretation.

Late to the game and really want to give the movie 4.5 stars but I'll give it 4 since there were some minor plot holes etc. Movie is downright beautiful from an imagery perspective and the pace of it is pretty smooth although its quite long.  Often you just want to see the space scenes tbh but also tbh they stick to those scenes more than not. I've read many critics or audience members claiming the movie is too complicated but to this I say BS. I come from an engineering background which of course did make the concepts immediately easy to get but to those who are regular folk claiming its complicated they literally explain nearly every aspect of the science  to the point where I was thinking okay okay we know. To be fair idk how many people do know which is why they explain this stuff.  The wormhole and dimensional aspects they don't bother explaining. Why? Because its 100% science fiction, only theories physics people dream about when they think about general relativity and the like.  Meaning no one knows since obviously we can't warp space or play with gravity.  The decisions made that were part of the danger plots were questionable but not horrible. The ending was satisfying overall and the cast did a good job of selling it. Again if you found the movie complicated then you prob weren't paying any attention considering its pretty linear. Movies good its not the amazing but makes up for it by being beautiful in the imagery, dialogue, and the cause and effect of the casts actions.

Started well, science behind it was on the whole pretty accurate. However the film was ruined by the ending which was crammed into about 20 mins, plot fell apart as a result

Christopher Nolan's 2014 film, "Interstellar" is a masterpiece of film and storytelling that demands multiple watches It's superb leading actors, Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, Jessica Chastain and Michael Caine bring out emotional beats they cut deeply into the viewers feelings and engross them in the characters' situations.
	Earth is a wind swept planet plagued by dust storms. Crops are dying and humanity has all but accepted its fate. Everyone that is, but the secret remnants of NASA. Discovering a wormhole by Saturn that leads to potentially habitable planets, Professor Brand (Michael Caine) enlists Cooper (Matthew McConaughey), an ex-NASA pilot, to fly the small crew of scientists through it in a last attempt to save the human race.
	"Interstellar" has mastered the art of letting you feel the emotions of the scene. Matthew McConaughey's acting perfectly encapsulates what the character Cooper is going through, his prowess and control over his emotions shining through in scenes with his daughter, Murph (Mackenzie Foy/Jessica Chastain). Every character feels realistic and grounded. Michael Caine's character, Professor Brand action's rfectly aligning with his system of beliefs brings truth to his decisions that feel rational. Brand (Anne Hathaway) makes decisions in this movie that alter its course and have real consequences making the movie feel raw and real.
	"Interstellar," all though complex and confusing if not thoroughly engaged, makes sense. Its sounds counterintuitive but everything makes internal sense within the logic of the movie. Time is slowed around heavy objects, so a black hole, being the most dense object in our universe, will screw with time in ways beyond our understanding. Everything in this film is foreshadowed, even from the opening shots it hints to what is to come. Upon a second watch through things fall into place bringing each part of the movie to another level.
	Hans Zimmer's score accents the film, making it greater than the sum of its parts. It deepens the emotions in each scene, leaving an impact on the viewer. In a movie where stress and sadness are felt most keenly, the score shines. It's haunting tones and flowing notes makes you feel the scene, feel the stress, feel the actor's mind. Another outstanding score from an outstanding composer.
	If you have not seen "Interstellar" you have deprived yourself of an experience I have found nowhere else. The thrilling story only gets better with each watch. Many people will say that the movie is too long or too confusing. They may be right. This movie is not for casual viewers. It is instead for the people passionate about film and storytelling, the people who are not daunted by hard topics or complex storylines, the people who would rather work to understand a movie on a deeper level then instead of being fed each plot point. All in all, "Interstellar" is a masterpiece. It's acting? Perfect. It's story? Perfect. Musical score? Perfect. It's impact on the viewer? Tremendous. It might possibly be Christopher Nolan's best film. "Interstellar" is a brilliant film that could be Christopher Nolan's magnum opus.

Christopher Nolan has created yet another masterpiece of a film. Interstellar is yet again another film that Christopher Nolan has put his talented filmmaking skills into. The film gave me an overall amazingly good impression. Between the detailed characters, the in-depth and complicated plot, and many more things, I could not be more pleased and impressed with this film. 

Interstellar tells the story of a future in which the people of Earth are headed towards extinction. The Earth has now started to have dust storms like the Dust Bowl. The main character, Cooper, was an ex-Nasa pilot who has given up his past life to become a farmer. When Cooper's daughter starts to find weird anomalies happening within their home, Cooper and Murph investigate. They realize it has something to do with gravity and use the coordinates they found to discover a secret Nasa base. Cooper is recruited to man a mission to another galaxy through a mysterious wormhole found near Saturn. He and other Nasa workers (Brand, Doyle, Romilly, and a few robots), must travel by Interstellar travel. They run into many problems that include time acceleration, Doyle's death and black holes. When they reach one of the "promising" planets, the astronaut that was already sent to explore (Mann) is in cryosleep. They wake him and then start to explore the new planet. When everyone splits up to do different things, Mann takes Cooper far away and then proceeds to fight him and cracks Cooper's helmet. Cooper then calls Brand as Mann escapes and Romilly dies in an explosion. Cooper and Brand try to stop Mann from boarding the space station that they have been using. When Mann fails to do so the right way he dies in an explosion that damages the station, Endurance. Cooper and Brand are available to reattach to the Endurance through an intense and amazingly crafted scene in which Cooper has to use his piloting skill to match the destroyed station. Because they do not have enough fuel to reach the other planet explored by astronaut Edmond, Cooper uses his skills agin to use the black hole and a way to launch themselves towards Edmund's planet. Cooper sacrifices himself to save Brand and goes into the black hole. He then blacks out and is in a mysterious tesseract which allows him to change the past. He uses this to send messages to Murph about how to save the entirety of the human race back on Earth. He realizes that he, himself, is the "ghost" that caused the anomalies in his home. While in this dimension, Cooper realizes that the human race of the future created it just for him. The tesseract starts to close and Cooper blacks out. He is discovered by the saved human race near Saturn and his life is saved. The movie ends with him and a much older Murph being reunited. She tells him to go to Brand who is habiting the new future world for the human race, and the movie ends with Cooper doing so.

Nolan did an amazing job at creating and implementing very diverse and detailed characters to his film. If these characters were not as good as they had been I feel that this movie would have been very boring and not very interesting. Between the smart astronaut and the simple farmer trying to make his way in the dying world around him, I feel that Cooper's character really made people see what the movie industry can show when it comes to interesting characters. That also doesn't even include the other main and secondary characters of this film that if they had not been included would have made the film boring and not very interesting in the character development category. Over the course of the entire film I believe the character development for each character, no matter how important or whatever age was portrayed by confident actors/actresses, made the film interesting and moved the story in a pace that I both liked and was intrigued by.

The techniques within this film also was something that helped to make this film very interesting and overall a great movie. I found that within the movie all the scenes are constantly changing to different shots. I believe that this is one of the key factors to why this movie kept me on the edge of my seat. If the shots had been long and drawn out there movie would have gotten boring, quickly. But Nolan did a great job at making sure the shots were always changing, whether it be a close shot of the characters in a ranger cutting to shots of the ranger flying or shots on the ranger itself, the shots were always enjoyable and full of details for the story. Along with the different shots I feel that the audio composition in this film was beyond spectacular. The audio was very suspenseful when it needed to and when it was suspenseful I was on the edge of my seat. The audio changing volume during scenes also helped to show me that I needed to pay attention or I would miss something important. It also helped to set the mood when needed and showed when the scenes were going to get action packed or were not going to be very eventful. With the overall plot of the movie being confusing for some I believe that these techniques were used to help guide watchers towards what the director and other filmmakers were trying to tell.

I believe that Interstellar is yet another masterpiece of a film. I personally think that Christopher Nolan did an amazing job with creating not only a very detailed and at some points, confusing plot, while also creating very important and detailed characters. I also believe that between the different shots, colors, and other key factors along with a great soundtrack, Nolan was able to get across what he wanted audiences and watchers alike to understand and appreciate when it came to Interstellar. In my opinion I believe this film is very much worth watching and will become a favorite for all watchers like myself. Especially those who are interested in futuristic movies that also deal with the ever so changing and vass detail of space.

I thought the director of the film Interstellar, Christopher Nolan, choose the best actors possible. Anne Hathaway, Matthew McConaughey, Matt Damon and Jessica Chastain really brought the movie to life and played the roles perfectly.

I thought this movie's plot was really well planned out. The movie starts out with the idea that the earth they live on is dying out and will soon not be able to support the humans on it. The main character, Cooper, and three other astronauts are sent up to space to try and find another planet to support human life. This mission is full of discoveries and breakthroughs as well as sadness and unfortunately death. The plot line throughout the movie keeps the viewer thinking and wondering what might happen next. 

As I mentioned earlier, I think that the acting in this film was amazing. I think that the actors that were chosen honestly portrayed the roles the best they could have. They hit every kind of character needed to make the film work. They had the positive and optimistic character, Murphy, the reasonable and confident character, Cooper, the selfish or "bad guy", Dr. Mann, and the followers or support characters, Romilly and Amelia brand. Lastly we have the character that is seen as bad by some and good by others, Professor Brand, he had the drive and determination to send people up to space with a hope to save the human race. These actors portrayed emotion so well which was such an important aspect in this movie. They truly made you feel connected to them through their acting.

I thought this movie had a very large range of shots and some great opportunities for awesome shots. They were able to portray a sense of emotion or intensity through the lens of the cameras. On top of the amazing camera work, the music added a whole different aspect to the movie and gave you such an amazing sense of time and also added emotion, anticipation, and suspense into the scenes and overall film.

A visual masterpiece dragged down by poorly drawn out characters and a plot weighed down by its own gravity which gets lost in space at times, swallowed not so much by wormholes but enormous plot holes!

At the start of the film we see farmer and father, Cooper tending his crops and chasing after Indian made satellites across his crop fields. 20 minutes further on and his commanding a high-tech NASA space craft that will be flying out of the solar system, through a wormhole to another galaxy in search of habitable planets for humankind to reach out too!

All very improbable, not helped by supporting characters we know or care little about so paper-thin are they drawn out, We're also told planet Earth is slowly dying along with its 7 billion inhabitants. And yet such a global catastrophe is never really emphasised other than for a few dust storms in Cooper's back yard!

Then there's the cameo of Matt Damon, who is completely wasted in a meaningless and time-consuming subplot that really doesn't advance the plodding plot very far.

The ending we could see coming almost an hour before, and never really gripped you the way some Nolan films can. Instead its all very nicely wrapped up the way we knew it would be, and we're left to wonder "After almost 3 hours, is that really it!?"

Interstellar é, sem sombra de duvidas, o filme mais lindo e magnifico que já assisti.

Por muito tempo, o considerei meu filme favorito. Com mais proximidade, fui conhecendo outras outras e aumentando meu repertorio cinéfilo. Dito isso, revi o filme após quase 2 anos - e já tendo o visto pelo menos umas 5 vezes; e devo dizer que estava um pouco receoso pois minha visão mudou muito com o tempo, mas fico feliz em dizer que minha visão me proporcionou outra experiencia, que diferente do que eu pensei, foi tão boa senão melhor do que das ultimas vezes.

Agora pude observar aspectos que antes nem notara, sejam mais técnicos ou envolvendo roteiro. Ao assistir em 4K, numa tela grande, fica bem claro que Nolan faz filmes para o cinema especificamente. Quem teve o privilegio de assistir essa obra no cinema não sabe a sorte que tem - provavelmente sabe sim rs. O IMAX faz toda diferente, e as melhores fotografias vem daqui. Você fica hipnotizado, quase que literalmente. Principalmente no buraco de minhoca, qual eu acredito ser a retratação mais linda e complexa. A caracterização do mundo funciona bem, com uma poeira mortal, sem contar nas plantações infestadas. Acredito que poderiam ter dito algo no subtexto para os países a fora, mas tudo bem, minha ligação com a trama e os personagens é tanta que nem penso nisso. E o que falar da OST de Hans Zimmer? A melhor dele, senão uma das melhores. Essa parceria com o Nolan é uma das melhores coisas do cinema. A retratação do universo mais essa trilha é simplesmente uma obra de arte completa. MasterPiece.

Eu gosto muito dos personagens, e as cenas dramáticas me pegam de jeito, principalmente nas primeiras vezes que assisti. O plot twist é maravilhoso, e pra quem gosta de viajar nas sci-fi da vida, se entregar ao mistério e não se acomodar a respostas, esse filme é pra você. E alguns "subplots" como um todo funcionam bem. Matthew McConaughey tá excelente, mais uma vez se provando um ator completo. Mackenzie Foy me surpreendeu, tendo um futuro muito promissor. Menções honrosas a Jessica Chastain, Matt Damon e Michael Caine, que estão excelentes.

O trabalho de mixagem e edição de som é muito bem feito, sendo obrigatório assistir com um fone de ouvido bacana pra imergir completamente. O filme tem 3 horas mas parece que se passam 1h e meia. Os planetas são magníficos, uma real experiencia IMAX. A caracterização de todos é ótima, mal dando pra acreditar que, de fato, foram filmadas na terra. Os personagens também são bem desenvolvidos, pelo menos os principais. Algumas coisas tu só pega na segunda ou sexta vez assistindo...

Enfim, Interstellar é uma obra obrigatória a qualquer cinéfilo, e tem tudo que um filme precisa ter para ser uma verdadeira obra de arte. Nora 10.

I am a 66-year-old movie buff.  For the past 50 years, whenever I was asked to name my favorite sci-fi film, I answered, "The Bride of Frankenstein".  (1935).  Until Interstellar was released.  

I was not a big fan of Christopher Nolan.  I HATED the Dark Knight Trilogy.  Then I saw Interstellar.  I was so impressed, I went back to the theatre the next day and saw it again.  Then I saw it a third time.

Then I bought the book of the screenplay.  It took multiple viewings and reading the script to convince me of one thing:  I believe that Interstellar is simply the best  Science Fiction Film.  Ever.

Directed by Christoper Nolan, starring Matthew McConaughey & Anne Hathaway. Who knew that a movie about gravity could be so light and heavy all at the same time. By this point in his career, Director Christopher Nolan has defined himself as a big budget film expert from redefining the scope of IMAX and uses of practical effects. Interstellar follows astronauts looking to find a new planet since earths days are numbered. Now this may sound like a cliche movie that’s been done before but this film is anything but cliche. By the end of the film, your emotionally drained by the vastness of worlds and suspense of how all of the plot points will hopefully fall into place. While the cast is large and has some heavy hitters in play, this is McConaughey’s film. He delivers a physical and emotional performance as a father that wants to save his family. No surprise from a Nolan film, this is visually stunning. Great use of camera work and practical effects to make this film feel like it’s all believable. By the end of the film it’s mixed by audiences who are either scratching their heads or somehow it just makes sense with the info that was given to us. At its core this is a movie about a Father and his Daughters relationship, realizing not even time and space can separate that connection.

Just watched a lecture by Nobel Laureate, theoretical physicist Dr. Kip Thorne at Cardiff University.  It inspired me to rewatch Interstellar again for the 5x now.  FYI,  Kip is a world-leading expert on the implications of Einstein's theory of General Relativity, from time travel to wormholes, and from black holes to gravitational waves.    Having won the Nobel Prize for being one of the founders of LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory), Kip was awarded the 2017 Nobel Prize in Physics.  Kip was Nolan's consultant for the entire movie, everything except moving though the worm hole is scientifically accurate and up to date with where we are in theoretical physics.  Rewatch and realize much of the movie is what would happen if traveling through a wormhole or seeing what a black hole actually looks like and we now have a real image to confirm Kip was right!

Interstellar is an absolute rollercoaster of a movie. The tone switches almost constantly, and, while that isn't necessarily an issue, it became noticeable fairly quickly. Of all his non-batman films, interstellar is the one clearly made specifically for the general theatre audience. While it has all of the classic Nolan moves, Interstellar clearly valued the visual style over the story. However, through this, Nolan still managed to make a very well made and compelling blockbuster. As I mentioned, a large part of why Interstellar works so well is the way the film looks. Almost every shot is inspired in a genius creative sense, the only exception to that is the surprisingly bland interior of the space ship, where most of the film takes place. While I understand the intention of the bland space ship interior, it simply doesn't fit with the visual style of the rest of the movie. One specifically impressive visual moment is the moment where they realize that the "mountains" are actually giant waves. This is something unlike what I have seen in any other movie, and that's something Nolan can do well. Nolan is able to make something completely new and inventive and introduce it to the medium of film without having it seem out of place. Overall, making something with as much creativity in the look of a film adds to the impact. Another unique aspect of Interstellar that added to the impact is the music, or, Hans Zimmer falls asleep on his Pipe Organ for two hours. Using a pipe organ shouldn't work, it should make the whole film feel like a trip to church, but, the pipe organ sound adds to the feeling of an empty void that is space, asking the question "are we alone" that Interstellar subtly focuses on throughout the film. Interstellar is full of these deeper themes. Although I do appreciate it, the themes that are presented aren't as unique as the rest of the film. The themes don't seem to have any meaning to the characters or the overall story, almost as if they were thrown in at the last minute. Too give an example of this, the ending where Matthew Mcconaughey sees his daughter one last time before she dies could have meant much more if he actually stayed to watch her die. Earlier in the film, Matt Damon's character mentions how the last thing a parent sees is their child. Contrasting this at the end would have made everything feel much more rounded, because, without it, Matt Damon's character serves no real purpose other than to make the movie about 20 minutes longer. Not to mention, the character is kind of flat, as are many characters in this film. Every character acts as an archetype, and are often more 2 dimensional rather than not. This is partially due to the dialogue. While Nolan has nearly mastered the art of making a film, dialogue has never been his strong suit. That is evident in Interstellar more than any other film, dis-including Dark Knight Rises. So, overall, the film's visual style is incredibly unique, and the more technical aspects all are near perfection. However, in Interstellar, it seems that Christopher Nolan put the way the film looks over the story.

The only movie to ever move me to tears, Interstellar turns Nobel prize-winning theoretical physicist Kip Thorne's physics equations into mind-blowing visual effects in a heart-wrenching epic drama about interstellar travel, the survival of humanity, and a father-daughter relationship that transcends spacetime.

Interstellar: Science that won hearts.

Interstellar, the brainchild of the Nolan brothers is nothing short of a cosmic revelation. McConaughey's Cooper and Hathaway's Amelia Brand join a team of astronauts to lead an expedition into space to battle extinction on Earth. Their mission is to find a habitable planet in another galaxy to which mankind can escape to, from our apocalypse-approaching Earth. The almost three-hours long adventure that follows is full of strange new worlds, a lot of techno-talk, and a fair bit of philosophical debates.

Interstellar is an astounding prototype of superior science fiction films, the kind which refuses to let you look away from the screen even when space suit-clad scientists discuss theoretical physics. On their mission to find a habitable, cognizable planet, the Cooper, Amelia, and the rest of the astronauts on the mission are removed from everything that defines them as humans. They have had to leave their families, their homes, and their jobs back on Earth to take on the Herculean responsibility of saving mankind from perishing on the soon-to-be-inhabitable Earth. Apart from this planned objective, they have no idea what lies their way. From entering a wormhole to setting foot on an ocean-planet to falling inside a black hole, they face all kinds of complex and scientific obstacles.
Hans Zimmer's background score helps in relaying the underlying thrill to the audience and lends a somewhat hypnotic effect to the film. Interstellar has just the right blend of science and fiction which makes it an enjoyable watch along with being thought-provoking and scientifically viable. Even after you have walked out of the theater, one thing you can be sure of is that this film will stay with you long after it has ended.

An underrated film that balances typical sci-fi conventions of space travel with the responsibilities of being a father in a simple rural world, Interstellar is deeper and smarter than your average sci-fi movie. It asks the most ridiculous questions that create the most ridiculous answers, which will leave you spellbound long after the film is over.

Interstellar is one of my favorite science-fiction and family oriented movies I have ever watched. It is a perfect depiction of a movie that makes you think outside the box (literally!) and needs at least two watches to fully grasp the ideas and concepts in the movie. As a science-geek myself, I thoroughly enjoyed the physics aspect of it. For instance, the concept of time and fifth dimension in the movie are the two things that stood to me the most. 
	As an astrophysical based movie, Nolan connects the science fiction story to a more sentimental aspect - family and love. Despite the movie having a deeper understanding and explanation of the alternative universe that exists, it emphasizes the importance of family. It also plays a major role in portraying the relationship between a father & daughter who undergo many sacrifices. 
	As the movie progresses, the understanding of the movie progresses too. What I find most intriguing about Interstellar is that it engages audiences from the get-go and the person will always be interested to know what will occur next. Overall it is a great watch for a person what likes to have a balance between physics, love and space!
