Christopher Nolan is some kind of magician. I can't remember the last time a movie had to work so hard to redeem itself from where it started to where it concluded. The first 45 minutes of this movie, give or take a few, were a real slog. Encumbered by some very clunky and cheesy dialogue, borderline ridiculous and completely jarring stunt casting, and an overly long prologue, Interstellar eventually becomes something else. Visually stunning, tense and thrilling, and emotionally resonant, I don't know how Nolan pulled it off. It's almost as much of a miracle as the one accomplished by McConaughey's character in the movie. I started off hating this film, but over the course of its nearly 3 hour run time I was totally converted. Despite some very serious flaws, I can't deny the effect the film ultimately had on me.

I managed to catch Interstellar the other day. Christopher Nolen rides again with this massive scale sci-if journey story that braids cutting edge special effects, amazing performances and a supremely inventive story together to make what is sure to be one of the year's landmark films. The movie stars Matthew McConaughey as Cooper, a NASA astronaut forced to become a farmer in a world where earth's natural resources have dwindled down to nearly nil. As Cooper struggles to raise his children during what seems to be humanity's final throws, a team of scientists, headed by Nolen favorites Michael Caine, Anne Hathaway and David Gyasi, put together a daring plan to save humanity by searching for new inhabitable world's beyond our galaxy and require Cooper's skill to get them there.

I really dug the hell out of this movie. As a fan of space travel myself, I really have to say that they did a great job at capturing a lot of the real math and science theory behind space travel, relativity theory and even some of the more edgy ideas about the characteristics of black holes. It's clear that the Nolen brothers Christopher and Jonathen did their homework while writing this script. The performances are also quite good here and Jessica Chastaine, who plays Cooper's grownup daughter, is especially impressive. These things married with the IMAX scope and the bigger than life special effects make this movie an absolute joy to watch. Everything is not all aces here as the film is not without its faults. Perhaps the thing I had the most problem with was the film's third act. The movie spends a long time setting up a very real and for the most part, a scientifically sound universe that is on par with 2001: A Space Odyssey and even to some degree it makes fun of a tropish, nonsensical and dumb way that the story could end as if to say, "we're smarter than that, c'mon, what do you take us for?" only to give in and end it that way anyway. At first I was ok with it but the more that I look at the film, the less the ending makes sense and the more the film starts to eat itself which was needless to say, really disappointing.

Overall, I still liked the movie and despite my issues with the third act, I recommend it, and if you can, spring for the IMAX because the scope and scale of the visuals are ridiculous! No television could ever do it justice. This film is for sure to be in talks to win an award of some kind for special effects in the coming months and it's well deserved. If you love liked Gravity or 2001: A Space Odyssey or Apollo 13, you are sure to like this too. Interstellar gets a 3.5...out of 5.

I finally made it to the theatre to watch Interstellar and it was definitely worth it. This was a hugely ambitious project by Christopher Nolan and although much of it was difficult to comprehend I just managed to follow the plot. With all hope of life on planet earth fading quickly Cooper leaves his two children to search for the possibility of life on another planet. While in space he receives word that it was never possible to bring the rest of mankind with them instead they were sent there to carry on mankind theirselves. Cooper and Brand refuse to leave their loved ones on earth to just die so they continue to search for the answer that will sustain human life on another planet. After communicating the answer to his daughter Murph on earth through another dimension Cooper is left for dead in space. Murph eventually saves mankind and Cooper is eventually rescued to witness this bizarre new world that mankind occupies thanks to his daughter. There he meets Murph who has aged greatly and is now on her deathbed. They  embrace and Murph tells Cooper to go save his colleague Brand who is on another planet waiting for someone to save her. Interstellar was an incredibly smart movie but also a story about love and mankind's will to carry on. I really enjoyed this movie and glad i decided to finally go see it.
Interesting concept ....will go to theatre and watch again

Exhilarating pacing, deep concepts of space and time (perhaps stretched, then again maybe not!). Didn't feel like almost 3 hours. If  its on at IMAX near you go see it!

"Interstellar" in one of those films that come around but once in a life time. The kind of film which transcends simple entertainment and becomes an experience. 
In years to come I will feel blessed to think back and know I was there. 

"I was there when Interstellar first came out and I saw it in the cinema opening week"
  
I can not truly compare it to any other space odyssey.  Because I can't really think of any film that really catches its majesty and scope. 

I settled in my seat not expecting  much at all. "This is Christopher Nolan who tried to make Bat-Man into Shakespeare much to my chagrin " 

But as my eyes glazed over and my mind whirled I couldn't help but think to my self "Now this is a film!" 

I have always had a vast imagination, and through my years of film watching most, if not all movies haven fallen short of what my imagination can create. 

interstellar come so close to what I can imagine its frightening. 
It's the perfect movie that I have been waiting for. 

The storyline is fascinating (unlike Nolan's other films which run just as long or longer then interstellar) The acting superb, the direction and pace a perfect blend of suspense and wonder. 

Add a dash of Einstein and adventure and you have a spectacle movie.  

The film seems to effortlessly explore themes of family, trust, connection, responsibility along with exploring the humans will. 
Though it comments on issues such as pollution, social conditioning, values and education. It is never preaching. 

This film is absolutely mind- boggling. 

For some odd reason the Academy has chosen to completely snub "Interstellar" at this years awards. 

Could it be this film is too big for Hollywood, on to much of a grand scale to be considered to be ranked beside lesser films. Because trust me after watching this movie it will take awhile to adjust to watching a "regular movie"  again, because this is an extra-ordinary film. 

It's scope is vast and though it is a big budget film it never loses its intimacy or tenderness. 
It is always brought back to relationships and people and connection and purpose. 
I think that is what Nolan's other films were actually missing: heart. 

This is Nolan's masterpiece. I can't imagine him ever topping it. 
 
This is the one he will be remembered for. 

Don't listen to anyone who slams this film. For anyone who can't see it's brilliance is blind or  jealous. 

Five stars out of five. Can't think of anything critical to say about it. 

Fantastic.

This film is, "Gravity" magnified. It tried to be profound, but instead it ends up sounding like a typical 4 year old trying to sound profound. Like that film, there's solid acting, and some great visuals, and some of the human interactions were also fine. However, while that story strained physics to it's breaking point, this one shatters through it as if they don't matter. Which would be fine, EXCEPT it uses existing physics to justify it's very premise and then ignores those same ones when they're inconvenient. Some scenes are mostly plausible, and then the next had me silently screaming at the screen for getting it so wrong. I also had figured out the basics of the climax fairly early on, so to me it felt kind of flat. The ending also makes no sense, but for reasons I can't get into without spoilers. If you really liked "Gravity" you may like this, but for me, while I by no means hated it, I can't recommend it either.

Very thought provoking and intelligent movie. Excellent sound effects and beautiful photography. Reminds me of two classic movies: 2001 A Space Odyssey and Contact. Very recommended to see in a movie theater.

Christopher Nolan, Sci-Fi's knight in shining armor returns for the first time since his conclusion of the Batman trilogy. Let me say, I was not expecting this. Nolan commonderes a doomsday type film, with the on-a-roll McConaughey casted to save it. Unfortunately for my expectations, it was not Nolan's best. Characters are a bit overdramatic, I do not think Hathaway was right for the role, but that's just me. But enough about the shortcomings, I gave this film 4 stars because it took Gravity another step forward. I don't care who you are, this film should excite and inspire you about the future of space exploration. The main character asks "why did we stop searching?" and I completely agree. It's fascinating beyond belief and given a fun plot twist at the end that sends your head spinning, even if it is unrealistic. No, Interstellar was not perfect, but who cares? Give it a chance.

Interstellar is probably the most highly anticipated film of the year, setting it up for the potential disappointment that comes with a film as over-hyped as this one most certainly is, while also granting it the space required for it to grow in what ever direction it needs to, its dreams un-tethered to the expectations associated with an unknown director's work, and allowing for its final grand gestures towards cosmic significance to feel genuine despite itself. Coming off of a string of seminal films that have succeeded in establishing Christopher Nolan as one of the greatest directors of his generation, Interstellar builds upon an already established and credible legacy, leaning on the iconographic cache of Nolan's name in order to attempt the making of one of the most sought after goals in Hollywood: the making of a space odyssey. Inevitably, Nolan pulls upon such unavoidable inspirations and sources as Stanley Kubrick and George Lucas in order to do so, but is still able to instill his impeccably distinguishable touch into his own work, giving his audience a film that is cinematically compelling, even if we have seen its like before. While Nolan's new space odyssey doesn't offer any new avenue into the sci-fi genre, stumbling over the convolutions of plot that occur in the narrative's utilization of time travel, it's hard not to stand in awe of the film's technical mastery. Watching Nolan's film is akin to recapturing the innocence of our collective youth, ephemeral in its impermanence, playful in its mimicry of its forebears, and awesome in its genuine sense of wonder, still caught up in the dreams of childhood that we have long since been shaken awake from.

Intersellar is deeply indebted, both in terms of narrative and aesthetics, to Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey, and as such sets off in search of new territory from the well of Kubrick's pervasive influence on both the genre and Nolan's film itself. By taking the very best aspects of Arthur C. Clarke's original screenplay and Kubrick's authorial vision, Nolan attempts to neatly repackage what audiences have already seen in a way that is surprising, fitted to modern times and his own cinematic sensibilities. Essentially reformatting Kubrick's classic vision of the omniscient wonder of space to a contemporary, ecologically driven narrative, wherein earth is becoming uninhabitable and depleted of sustainable farmland, Nolan pulls on the grandness of the space odysseys of the 1970's and 1980's, inhabiting a dreamscape that was once pure fantasy made into a more tangible reality within the scope of his film. One of the most stirring aspects of Interstellar is its fascination and intimate love for deep space exploration, reinvigorating a dying enthusiasm for space travel and the sci-fi epic that has long lain dormant in our collective subconscious for nearly a decade, only to be reinvigorated once more by the majesty of film, propelling us out of our seats and into the stars. Interstellar is by no means Nolan's greatest achievement, unmemorable in its constant allusions and trace resemblances to such classics as Kubrick's aforementioned odyssey, but its level of visual tenacity and outright beauty is a marvel to behold, urging you to watch more closely, and revel in the silence of yet another small step for man, leaping into the void in order to reinvigorate our long lost love for celestial drama.

Probably the most glaring criticism to be made about the film comes in the laziness of its many conveniences and contrivances of plot, most notably being the overly sappy and Kubrick-esque third act, wherein the familial drama that forms much of the film's thematic center is married to the fictive surrealism of the plot's poorly delivered sci-fi tropes. Granted, the climactic portion of the film that bears the brunt of a lot of this specific source of criticism looks remarkably similar to Kubrick's final sequence in 2001, but where Kubrick was driven by the camera, alienating and isolating his viewer's in the process of crafting some of the most well edited and composed shots in terms of cinematography, while alienating and confusing his audience in the process, Nolan's film is interested in the characters, their stories and connections to one another as important as Nolan's debts and connections to his audience. While certain aspects of the familial drama do feel Spielbergian in their overt manipulation of the audience's sympathies and investment in the film, it's also a thematic point of fundamental significance that serves to anchor the viewer's investment over the course of the film's near three hour run time. What's more, this familial drama is set up clearly in the film's script from act one, is seamlessly carried over through an emotionally taut second act, and finally grants climactic closure in a third act that feels well earned and genuine, sentimentalism carrying the drama and action throughout. As was the case in Douglas Trumbull's 1972 ecological fable Silent Running, Nolan implements genre filmmaking in order to tell a story of the warmth and compassion of humanism, setting his film apart from the cold, nihilistic detachment of Kubrick, and making Interstellar stand out on its own, definitively Nolan-esque. It might not be the most memorable film within Nolan's oeuvre, but it's certainly one of the year's best, populated by characters that are compelled by the cinematic vision of an auteur, and carried on the shoulders of the script's structural, if not scientifically cogent, mastery.

Without a doubt, Interstellar is a film that will be talked about for weeks to come, and will be the center of a lot of Oscar Buzz as we head into awards season, but it likely won't be the recipient of the Academy's final selections for artistic recognition. Nolan's admirable attempt at the space odyssey often feels a little too redundant in its wistful reminiscing of what has come before, leaving the viewer in a state of disaffectedness as the credits begin to roll, left with the knowledge that the film was in fact directed by Christopher Nolan, his name holding more aesthetic power and cohesiveness than the film itself, lacking the character of The Dark Knight and the clarity of Inception. The stylistic indebtedness that the film holds to the sci-fi heyday of the 1970's and 1980's is a welcome resurgence that strives to carry on the example set by Alfonso Cuaron's Oscar winner from last year, and next year's The Martian directed by Ridley Scott seems to be further promise of the genre's reemergence as critically and commercially viable. However, Interstellar's grandness might also be its downfall, just as big cinematically as Star Wars, Alien, or Blade Runner, but not nearly as vital, lacking a certain authorial urgency and heart that defines the three aforementioned classics, Nolan merely playacting as Kubrick in a dilapidated playground of adolescent exuberance, contented but not inspired. For all of its cinematic effectiveness on its own terms, Interstellar struggles to surpass its inspirations, treading water in the tidal pools of recursive nostalgia, the vast ocean of independent innovation lying beyond its comfortable recesses in the sand.

"Interstellar" is undoubtedly writer-director Christopher Nolan's most ambitious and personal movie to date but nonetheless it is not the strongest addition his impressive resume (I still think "The Dark Knight" is his definitive movie). There is so much to admire here but the movie has its? flaws.

It is set in the future where earth is becoming more and more difficult to live in on food scarcity that is driving a secret NASA to find life on other planets through traveling through a black hole near Saturn. The movie's central idea revolves around the relativity theory and the difference in the passage of time through space.

Here is what I liked; 1) the movie is undoubtedly beautiful to look at (a planet with gigantic waves is especially breathtaking) and seeing it in IMAX definitely helps, 2) one long sequence more than half through that showcases Nolan's directorial strength building up a great deal of tension (the scene cuts through events on an ice-cold remote planet and on earth), 3) the simple yet brilliant single-note score by Hans Zimmer, 4) the acting - Matthew McConaughey follows up his Oscar win with another great performance as a loving father willing to sacrifice his time with his kids for the good of humanity and Jessica Chastain (one of the best actresses around in my opinion) as the older version of his hard-headed yet smart daughter (MacKenzie Foy of the last Twilight movie does a good job as the younger version of his daughter), and 5) most importantly, in the midst of all the complexity: there is one simple message in the movie: love as a drive for one's actions portrayed through a father-daughter relationship.

At a running time of nearly three hours, the movie tests the audience. I watched the movie twice: the first time it felt overlong (could have easily lost 30 minutes or so with the first hour especially slow) and too complicated for its own good (at times it feels as if one is watching a complex physics lesson). The second viewing was far better as I got to admire nuances in the plot (watching it knowing what will happen) but a certain twist in the film's final act was still a far too complex and far-fetched. The second problem is Anne Hathaway (the film's leading lady) as MConaughey's space companion and the daughter of a great scientist (Michael Caine) who's the mastermind behind the mission. She is a bit one-note here and the character isn't properly fleshed out. "Interstellar" is a movie that demands a second viewing and I am sure you will like it more the second time. Nominated for 5 Oscars: Original Score, Production Design, Sound Editing, Sound Mixing, Visual Effects.

As a grown woman who lost her father to cancer when I was 19, I am undoubtedly biased. I would imagine that any woman with an imperfect relationship with her father, whether that be because of death, abandonment, estrangement, or any other reason, would find the film fulfilling. It brought a lot of feelings and memories to the surface and then played them like violin strings. It was the good kind of hurt; the kind that eases some of that tension from grieving. That pain hasn't gone after eleven years and I don't imagine it ever will. It certainly grows easier to deal with, and a good cry is always a great release.

Regardless of any other aspects, good or bad, one cannot enjoy a movie without relating to its characters on some level. The kinship I felt with Murph was the anchor for me. The film isn't about space exploration or Earth being no longer able to sustain human life; it's about the relationship between a father and his daughter.

With a 72% Tomato, this is Nolan's (as director) "worst" film. It is thoroughly enjoyable and the pacing is excellent--quite important on a near-three-hour movie. One must suspend their disbelief a hair more than usual for Nolan's films, but a little bit of popcorn seems to do the trick.

For a film that sets out to detail man's first steps towards the stars, Interstellar takes a long time to leave the ground. By the time it does there are already signs that, as writers, Messrs Nolan have fallen foul of one of the most common traps laid before them - namely they have failed to keep it simple. A knock on the door informing astronaut ace Cooper that his country needed him would surely have cut through the lengthy process he undertook to strap himself back into the cockpit. That and an annoyance with his bratty daughter's selfish attitude was already turning me away from a film that had an excellent premise, and with an unlimited budget should therefore have delivered more.
Further black holes of various types appear in the plot so whilst the effects are stunning at times I was always conscious of being in the theatre as opposed to being suspended in space. Quite the reverse was the case with the Kubrick classic 2001:A Space Odyssey, the film with which this has been so liberally compared. Although the Kubrick take on man's space quest was not simple in concept, it kept its feet on the ground at all times before hitting the viewer in the solar plexus at the end.
For me Interstellar was a fair effort but one that ultimately got lost in its own wormhole.

The formula is there: visually stunning, decent casting, highly sentimentalized and more visceral than your average Nolan film- yet it somehow still manages to plummet to such irreconcilable depths. Interstellar suffers from a convoluted plot, under-developed characters, and sadly, the spectacle does not redeem it whatsoever.

Certainly not a film to shy away from ambition, Interstellar's best bits come in the shape of stunning visuals (attend a big screening if possible) and an expectedly powerful performance from McConaughey. However, the complexity of the plot may bemuse audiences who fail to pay it their full attention, which is difficult to do for almost three hours. Furthermore, it treads a line between scientific rambling and sentimentality - the latter struggles to weave away from excessive. I would recommend it to anyone up for a test of endurance and intellect, but I will not be watching it again in fear of dedicating a large percentage of my life to this production.

"One of the Years Best Films... Extraordinary!"

Calling Interstellar anything less than extraordinary is erroneous.  The film is a masterpiece and a brilliant work of art, only flawed by it's own intelligence.  The movie had me feeling like a kid again, like seeing Jurassic Park or Star Wars for the first time.  It's so grand and unimaginable, you stare up at it and wonder "how did they do it?"  Then right when you think you've seen it all you realize you are in for so much more.  Interstellar is a magnificent ride that pushes the boundaries of what movies are and can achieve.  It doesn't just reach for the stars, no, it flies past them, through them, around them, and beyond to easily become one of the years best films!

Filled with edge of your seat excitement and stunning visuals, Interstellar is a marvel of a film to experience.  An impressive cast and remarkable sets make the story rich and vibrant; equally matching the movie's technical prowess.  Not to mention some incredible science, most of which flew over my head, but if you just go with it and enjoy the films brains and brawn you'll realize you are in for quite the treat.  Interstellar is an intelligent and entertaining movie, an epic that is easily one of the best adventures to grace cinemas in the last decade of filmmaking.  

Christopher Nolan's film is hard to look away from and by the end you may even wish it were longer.  The incredible worlds of Interstellar are fascinating and you want to explore them further.  However, each planet's obvious threat to the lives of the characters in the film is so overwhelming that I genuinely feared each one.  I often felt my body tensing up, becoming uneasy, and often being crushed under mountains of emotion.  The film is highly effective in its ways and brought me to pieces many times.  I admire it for not holding back and taking a hold of me as it did.  

Interstellar just can't be compared to anything else.  Even if you don't like the story, or find it pretentious, too complex, or long... you simply can't deny the grandness of it.  The beauty of it.  The overwhelming sense of wonder and amazement in every frame.  The movie reaches higher than most dare to take their stories and for all those reasons it becomes masterful and magnificent! 

FINAL SCORE = 5/5 Bear Paws

So I will not lie to you: I walked into the Christopher Nolanâ??s latest film thinking it was going to be some slightly thought provoking space film with a star studded cast and not much more. In my mind, the three hour movie was going to be an offspring/wannabe of Alfono Cuaronâ??s Gravity with a dark Nolan-esque twist. Itâ??s superstar cast mirrorâ??s Cuaronâ??s motion picture last year that earned him a Best Director Academy Award so that combined with the space footage in Nolanâ??s preview led me to a naÃ¯ve conclusion.
 
A naÃ¯ve conclusion destroyed as soon as I stepped into the theater.
 
Iâ??ve never experienced a movie quite like Interstellar. The entire movie made me feel like I was literally floating and spinning for three hours. A constant confusion yet amazement as to what was playing on the screen before me. The combo of the whole apocalyptic dust ridden world that needs intense saving mixed with a DILF ex-astronautâ??s emotional battle to leave his family for what could be hundreds of years Earth time made for a science fiction picture that kept you on the edge of your seat with an utterly confused look on your face. What set this movie a part for me from other space themed movies was how it focused less on outer space special affects (though it had its fair share of insanely cool shots of what is out there) and more on the actual physics and logistics of space travel and the emotional journey of the characters.
 
My brain does not perform on a science level. I took physics my Junior year of high school and though I walked out with an A- (only because we got to bring in formula notecards to every exam), no amount of high school physics could prepare me to wrap my head around some of the concepts in this movie. The whole â??I can leave to space and come back looking not a day older but you will be 50 years older than me because space time is measured differently than Earth timeâ?? thing is just something that I still to this day have trouble understanding, but that Interstellar helped clear up for me. The scene at the end with Cooper (McConnaughey), a still crisp adult, and his daughter, a now old woman, was breathtaking depiction of the power of time. If I had an issue with this movie it was that it was mega confusing at times. I found myself asking questions and trying to fill in the blanks and although sometimes I feel that once you confuse your audience, you lose them, this movie was an acception. I was confused, but it was a pleasant confusion. It was like eating something delicious and having no idea what it is. A pleasant misunderstanding that I never wanted to end.
 
Nolan chose to center his movie all on the power of love. A surprising move on our boy Christopherâ??s part compared to his other films, but in my eyes that is what set it a part from his other work. Nolan wrote the screenplay along side his brother and we know from his other movies like Inception the way his brain works is unlike any other human on this planet. The guy doesnâ??t even own a cell phone or have an email account; heâ??s too cool for that. He much rather spend his time writing mind blowing screenplays about trying to attempt to save the human race by travelling to three possible life supporting planets via a black hole. Like itâ??s whatever.
 
The characterâ??s emotional journeyâ??s and the intense conditions and imperative nature of the mission given to them made for an incredible combination. You could feel the tension that was laced in thoughts and actions mixed with their knowledge that it was their rightful duty to attempt to save the human race during the astronautâ??s journey out of our solar system. Hathaway and McConnaughey both tapped into their character's human nature so beautifully. The portrayed on the screen the battle between our duties to those we love and our duties to what we need to do. The breathtaking montage of Cooperâ??s sonâ??s logged videos once he got off the first possible planet for life that made 24 Earth years go by was by far my favorite part of the film. Maybe itâ??s because I was sitting in my tears by the end or maybe because of my prolonged crush on Casey Affleck who played the son once he got older, but whatever it was it stood out to me the most. It was raw, real, and the first incarnation of the movieâ??s ultimate end message which in my eyes was love answers and solves all.
 
Awwww, we got all sappy! How sweet. No, but really go see this movie. I am not talking renting it on demand next Spring in your PJs on a rainy day because you need to be mentally prepared for this. I am talking get in your car, mentally prepare yourself, drive to an IMAX theater, get a bag of popcorn (large because THREE HOURS PEOPLE), and experience this movie. That is the only word I can give itâ??it is an experience.

I know this had been said many times, but it really is a "2001" for a younger audience. I love 2001 but the pacing is a little slow and this movie is paced a little better for the modern viewer. The only part that was weird was towards the end when it seemed like I was having an acid trip, but 2001 kind of did that too.

So close to perfection, but just not there. As Christopher Nolan gets closer to fifteen years of directing his efforts continue to improve, resulting in what in my opinion is his finest film yet. Interstellar reminds me very much of Robert Zemeckis's Contact in how close it comes to perfection, but left a handful of critics with a sour taste in their mouth. What do I think that did that? That it WAS edging perfection, but just really seemed to lack something. Was it the acting? Well you could hardly call it weak. Strong performances from Oscar winners and nominees McConaughey, Hathaway, and Chastain made it incredibly difficult to choose a stand out performer, but to my surprise (despite my loathing of most chid actresses), i have to give that to the barely 14 year old Mackenzie Foy (since i can't give it to the robot). To my delight she did what most child actresses are unable to do. She portrayed emotion without making me angry, and actually made me care for her. In fact the only weak note I found with the acting was, much to my surprise, Caine. More of a lack of a character actually, I found it hard to believe that someone like him was capable of doing what he did. Was it the story? Very simply put, no. Nolan, par usual, wrote and directed like the most seasoned of all directors. Was it the visual/audio? God no, every moment of Interstellar was a masterful example of how a director can use modern technology to advance his film, and another classic Zimmer soundtrack that unfortunately seems might be one of it's only chances at an oscar. Then what was it? Well you could argue the lack of a love interest, you could argue that its too long and lost peoples interest, and you could even argue that the story didn't make sense, but nobody seems to be able to put their finger on the problem. The only problem I see, is like 2001 a Space Odyssey one of the greatest films of all time and didn't even win best picture, Interstellar is ahead of it's time, and like with 2001, one day people will look back at it and ask how it did that boyhood, or birdman movie win best picture instead of it. If you have beefs with my review you can feel free to message me.
god plot with an unexpected twist at the end. its almost refreshing to have a space movie be so different and relatable for once

This is an absolute clusterf*ck of a film. It doesn't know what it wants to be and it's had the kitchen sink thrown at it. At times it feels like Batman in space, others a bit like 2001. It has a stinking script where a lot of the time the actors are having to explain to the audience what it's all about. Other times trying to create drama about problems with quantum physics. It needed about 75% of the ideas chucked out and to get back to simple storytelling, and to decide what that story is. I'm sorry, but throwing in stunning space vistas is not enough to make up for it. And unfortunately 2001: A Space Odyssey has already been done - save your $35 at the iMax and watch that instead.

There is no sound in space and films tend to skip over that in order to make their movie more familiar to audiences. I'd recommend people check out the movie if scifi, space travel, end of the world, quantum mechanics, etc. interest them at all... or if they simply want to see Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, Jessica Chastain, and Michael Caine in a movie directed by Christopher Nolan

Zimmers score in its own I'm sure would sound great but I felt it was the most distracting part of the film, intensely and uneasily campy in many places that didn't ever seem to catch up to the current scene it was attempting to escort. It felt like a Kubrick film a la 2001 space odyssey, and maybe it was meant to....I just didn't like it.

This was bold from Nolan. Besides the opening scene, the first 30 minutes was booo-ring, but proved to be a great build-up for the rest of the movie. It ran smoothly, despite one could argue about Nolan's clean-cut style. But that's what Nolan does - creates puzzles, creates worlds. I loved the juxtaposure of two world-stands: living for a great, noble idea and living for the human contact, for the family. We should learn how to balance both and transfer energy from one to another. Besides, it's a homage to any director who spends much time away from home so he can create meaningful experiences like Interstellar certainly is. The science is good and believable, the insights about human nature are well-placed and relevant. It is ground-breaking in its cinematography aswell as in Nolan's grit to deal with a subject calm-headedly, with respect. The soundtrack is typical Zimmer but with a twist, and not only that the performances are A+ but the personalities and wits of the actors work well together, creating a good atmosphere.

This review is chalk full of spoilers.  You have been warned.

Visually, it was well done.  It was pretty to watch.  But no amount of direction can distract me from the Gargantua sized plot holes in this sucker.  Putting aside the overly technical "scientific" stuff like time travel, hibernation sleeps where they stopped aging, the seemingly magical fuel that lasts for over 2 years of continuous movement through space with multiple landings and take-offs, none of the motivations make any sense to me.  The entire happy ending of the movie was based on Plan A, but the existence of plan A didn't make logical sense.  I fail to see Professor Brand Sr.'s advocation of building this giant spaceship that (as far as he's sure) will never work.  Why would he ever think that sinking the entire planet's limited resources into this ship, that only a handful of people even know about anyway, would be a good use of resources?  It just does not compute in my brain and I cannot understand Caine's character's motivation.

Then there's Plan B, which we're told is the "real" hope for the planet; sending a bunch of frozen embryos up into space to start a new population that way.  We're ensured that they made sure to include lots of genetic diversity...what they did NOT ensure was that they sent enough women up on the spaceship to actually act as surrogates for all these embryos.  One woman.  That's it.  One woman is tasked with birthing a new population?  With the low success rate of IVF under the best of circumstances, let alone in space without any dedicated equipment or conception specialists, they were literally putting all of their eggs in one "basket."  Assuming she does manage to get pregnant every time she's implanted and is quite happy to be barefoot and pregnant, space style, AT BEST the fate of womankind is to be no better than glorified breeding mares for at least the next several hundred years.  Whoopee.

These are just the most glaring problems with the overall plot (again, ignoring the technicalities of all the "science"), but the entire movie is so inconsistent with character motivations that it was distracting and completely jarred me out of the movie experience.  Hathaway dooms them to losing an extra 10 years or so when she decides to run AWAY from the giant wave that comes every hour or so and destroys everything so that she can retrieve the data.  WHY WOULD THEY NEED THAT DATA?!  Clearly this planet is not going to support our new humanity, would with the 70 story tall waves every hour.  What is her motivation supposed to be here?  Then, in another fine example of the insidious sexism in this movie she has to be damsel-in-distress carried back to the ship by the robot TARS (who, by the way, is the only character I actually understood the motivation for and found appealing.)  Silly women, when will they learn.  Later she waxes poetic about how her great love for Edmunds is probably some "science" that we just don't understand yet pointing us towards the right path.  I literally scoffed out loud.

And Matt Damon...what?  What was his end game?  So he was sick of being alone, so he decided to commandeer the....empty space craft?  O....kay... The best part of that whole planet was when he was blown up mid-pompous sentence.  Sadly, the token black guy was (of course) killed on this planet as well, which is unfortunate because after TARS he was my favourite character.  I am still completely unclear on how that explosion came about though....did Mann somehow rig the robot to explode?  It's possible they explained this and I just missed it, but if his end game was to commandeer the space craft and leave them behind anyway, then what was the point of the bomb?

Finally, the hail Mary that saves humanity is McConaughey transmitting the necessary quantum data to Murph over time using the second hand of the watch he left with her.  Now, I'm not a physicist, but wouldn't it take a hell of a long time to transmit that much data in morse code?  I can't imagine that that would be a tiny amount of data.  Also, all the views into the room were her as a child, and the watch was not morse coding, so how did it just happen to start doing it when she started watching it?  How does she know that this is the beginning of the message and not the middle of such a large message.  We never saw the adult Murph in the room from McConaghey's perspective...

Finally, somehow Magical McConaughey survives traveling through a singularity.  Again, I am the first to admit that I am not a physicist of any kind, but I am fairly confident that there's no way that could ever happen.  They should have just killed McConaughey off.

In short, a huge disappointment of a movie that barely hangs together.

I will re-watch this once I get a hold of a copy. The cinematography is generally stunning; I stopped once mid-film to notice how tense I was. Then Matt Damon popped up and I was like "wuh?" Indeed, Matt Damon seems to blast into the film only to complicate things and just as quickly he blows an O-ring and explodes.  The short arc that features Damon and the tension between epic and romance vis academic dishonesty and honesty is as provocative as it is short and left unexplored. Anyway, the film's most phenomenal feature is its thematization of time via relativity theory. This sturdy theme really carries the film though it doesn't seem to mean much in the end.

Now I am no physicist, but the bookshelf-shaped anomaly that began the movie, the signal from the 5th dimension, seemed a bit distracting. From the very little I know and can casually discover on the internet, gravity is a good medium for a dramatic event that revolves around the fifth dimension. However, it might have been just a bit overkill. In some sense, this movie is bookended by odd and needlessly inexplicable concepts. I hope that over-elaborate-for-the-purpose-of-being-correct science fiction plots aren't the way of the future. I will certainly be sad if science fiction loses its capacity to comment on society and human foibles because writers and audiences begin to mistake scientific plausibility for artistic excellence. The most nightmarish dystopia is one in which my students' insipid thesis statements are vindicated by all contemporary art ("Moby Dick is a great work of art (or "is relatable" BARF) because Melville tried to be very accurate about whaling practices"). BARF BARF.

Epically scored, intelligently shot, and well acted, Interstellar is possibly the best Sci-Fi drama I have seen to date.  The movie is paced nicely, and at some points I found my jaw agape from the sheer intensity and risk inherent to the plot.  By describing sometimes complex scientific laws and properties through analogy, I (a pre-medical student well-versed in general science) only had to suspend my disbelief a few times to maintain a healthy STEM-gasm.  Finally, despite its three hour run time, Interstellar seems to make use of the concept of time dilation that invigorates its plot.  The movie progresses without blaring notice, leaving the audience feeling as if we jumped into a worm hole ourselves when the credits roll.

Put some of the exaggerated science aside and what you get is a very thought-provoking film that is also an audiovisual feat. The vast emptiness and soundlessness of space is seldom so artfully displayed. The score is also excellent. Well worth the cost of admission.

Both plot and science too convoluted (atrocious plausibility grievances not included since Nolan thankfully unabashedly threw that goal out of the window very early on in the story), dialogue and character direction too awkward, and cinematography too frustratingly static and short-sighted. There were a few moments of great other-worldly wonder, but Interstellar tried to be too many movies, failing in one way or another at each of them. And I sure hope that I never again have to hear an astronaut feel the need explain to another astronaut that black holes are so dense that even light can't escape. After this and "Gravity," maybe big-budget (mass-market) astronomy sci-fi is just destined not to sit well with me.

Interstellar Movie Review!

I found myself arguing to going to see this movie. Not because I heard it was bad/good, but because I wasn't ready for it. Interstellar is a visionary possibility of the future that the world might hold. And it was glorious.

The premise is thus: The world as we know it is coming to an end. A team of Explorers are finding possibilities of leaving the Earth in search for planets able to support our necessities. Our story follows an ex-astronaut who rejoins them in a grand expedition throughout the possibilities outside of our galaxy.

I have to say, I love this movie. This was easily one of the best movies of 2014 for me. The acting here was great. Everyone's contribution just seemed superb. It was mesmerizing. I felt connected with these people since the first 10 minutes.
The world is alive with colour. The visuals are very impressive and very easily to lose yourself in them. This is why I harass a lot of movies with CGI; because when movies like these that come out and look great, this (and more possible outcomes) are the best to see.

The story-line is immense. It teaches a very profound possibility into the future of mankind. It is suspenseful, long, and riveting. Some can find it boring; since most of the movie focuses on the suspense and the longitude of the movie rather than the action. I digress.

I recommend this movie to the fullest. I great spectacle to behold. Also, bring a butt cushion, because the sucker is about 2 hours 40 minutes long.

Interstellar is a film about a man who must leave his family to explore uncharted lands in the depths of space in the hopes of saving humanity. The inhabitants of Earth have turned to farming, as a sort of futuristic "dust bowl" has swept across the lands, devastating everything in its wake. Though the dust bowl is left unexplained (for good reason) it is an interesting way for Nolan to explore what future generations may have to go through, assuming the current one doesn't get its act together. After becoming comfortable with all of the characters on Earth, Cooper is sent into space with Brand (and two other characters I don't remember) to locate three planets that could possibly support life.

This movie is a technical feat. Nolan has always delivered in effects, always trying to make things look as real as possible. This means that Nolan generally tries to use practical effects, rather than CGI. And this becomes quite apparent throughout the film (he makes it pretty obvious in many scenes, such as when Cooper drives a truck through a corn field). The beauty and scale of the movie also really make the audience feel like the film is indeed an epic masterpiece.

Though the movie boasts a very interesting story with excellent characters, the movie cannot be the true masterpiece it aspires to be. The theme of "love is the only force that transcends dimensions" is very cheesy and, honestly, done very poorly. The theme feels more like excessive weight that doesn't strengthen the movie, but bogs it down. I also have big problems with the how the movie resolves itself. From the first five minutes of the movie, I knew exactly what the plot twist was going to be. The movie was not subtle and made everything far too obvious. Though I didn't know HOW the movie was going to resolve itself right from the beginning, I knew after about an hour in when they introduced the black hole.

(possible SPOILERS in the final paragraph)

Plot twist aside, what really bothered me about the ending was the execution. The last fifteen minutes of the movie are utter garbage in every way. I only gave this film 4 out of 5 stars because I tried to forget how bad the ending was. The end of the movie is an unnecessary epilogue that ruins everything the movie was working toward. The true end of the movie, in my opinion, was when Cooper entered the black hole and finished his mission. Funny, it's as if Nolan knew the only way to better himself was to leave the stratosphere. In a not-too-distant future where technology is almost obsolete and food is scarce, an ex-engineer-cum-farmer is recruited for a highly skilled and dangerous mission to explore potential habitable planets on the other end of a mysterious wormhole. With the plot so far out, the soul so profound and the subject matter so inspiring, only a master like Nolan could build the narrative to such insane heights, wrap things up sufficiently and still find times to move us to tears and drop our jaw by showing us things we never thought possible. Interstellar is a vivid, captivating, all-consuming assault on the senses. And the viewer is absolutely at the core of the experience. Each element has been created and tuned to allow you to express yourself anyway you wish, and give you just enough breadcrumbs to figure out the script's secrets on your own. And that amazing focus has produced a breathtakingly intimate film that is also the most epically grandiose and beautiful experience this lowly reviewer has ever been through. Anchored by Zimmer's epic score, amazing performances from the cast and Hoyte Van Hoytema's perfect cinematography, Interstellar is pristine, intelligent, beautiful, inspiring and immensely moving. Life will never be the same
I have grown tired of Christopher Nolan. But, I have to admit, "Interstellar" touched my heart. I particularly loved the travel through space and time.

As a farmer in the last days of meaningful agriculture, at first Cooper(Matthew McConaughey) might seem like the last person to chase after a drone with his kids in the truck.  But then he used to be a pilot for NASA, flying and even crashing spaceships.  That same sense of adventure leads him to a mountain where NASA is now conducting business, such as it is, under the leadership of Dr. Brand(Michael Caine) who has bad news and good news.  The bad news is humanity is screwed.  The good news is only on earth, as there is a wormhole inconveniently parked near Saturn that might lead to habitable worlds in another galaxy.  Meanwhile, John Crichton and Rygel look at each other sheepishly.

While yes "Interstellar" does take the audience places it has not been before, to actually call it ambitious would be something of a misnomer.  That comes down to a lack of imagination for a movie that borrows from multiple sources, has some seriously loopy physics and worst of all did not need its earth bound first act and accompanying incomplete world building, nor its extended epilogue which probably did not happen anyway, supported by at least one line of dialogue.(It gives an explanation, not the explanation for how Cooper found NASA.)  While the movie could have definitely used a more unconventional lead character(read into that what you will), this is definitely Jessica Chastain's movie, from when she first shows up on screen, brittle strength and all.
Waste of time. Far too long and at times feels like it is being streached by yet another 10th minutes with a last minute idea to add another twist to the rather boring story.

People aren't gonna like me for not enjoying this movie as much as others, but, the hell with it!

MVP: Chris Nolan's directing and the amazing acting of Matthew McCanehy. 
Biggest Flaw: the Mann scene.

Starring: Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, Michael Caine, and Jessica Chastain.
Directed By: Christopher Nolan
Written By: Jonathan Nolan and Christopher Nolan
Rated: PG-13

In the future, earth has become a dust bowl and mankind is starving. Cooper, a former astronaut turned farmer, is recruited by NASA after he stumbles upon their secret plan to leave Earth and discover a new habitable world for the planet's remaining populace. He pilots a four person team into a wormhole in hopes to find humanity's last hope at survival.

I went in not knowing much about this film. I saw the trailer once a few months ago and tried to avoid any spoilers or hype for it after that. I kept it in the back of my mind until it came out and was lucky enough to catch it on an IMAX screen (not a genuine one, but one of the smaller screens that my friend refers to as Lie-MAX). I have to say it was an incredible movie experience, not just because it was in IMAX, but as a film itself. It has easily become one of my favorites of the year thanks to its great performances, beautiful visuals, and one of Hans Zimmer's best scores.

Sometime in the last few years, Matthew McConaughey has turned into an incredibly talented actor (yeah I didn't think I would ever type those words either). A lot of people scuffed at him playing an astronaut, but he works great in the world the Nolan's made. In this world, mankind doesn't need men to fly space shuttles anymore, but grow corn instead, and he fits in that mold perfectly as a pilot turned farmer.
One of the other people joining McConaughey on his journey through the stars is Anne Hathaway, an actress who continues to impress with each new role I see her in. She continues to do an excellent job with her role in Interstellar.
Another performance worth mentioning would be Bill Irwin as the voice of the robot TARS, whose simplistic design was fantastic and I like they didn't try to go to complicated with it. TARS is one of the few times you will get to chuckle in an emotionally heavy movie.

Despite how much I loved the movie, I do admit it does have its faults so I can understand where some of the people who disliked it are coming from.
The audio is incredibly loud, so much so that some of the dialogue becomes hard to hear (I didn't really have a problem because often the parts that were muffled were repeated later). I do like how those moments contrasted the silence of the exterior moments of the ship in space, so I didn't mind them.
The third act was a bit hard to swallow (which happens with Nolan sometimes). I found myself asking "Really? That's the answer" a few times, but it at least made sense and isn't something you'll see coming a mile away. It took a little bit to convince me, but I ended up accepting it because I enjoyed the movie so much.
Even with those problems, I still enjoyed it. It's a powerful film and I felt emotionally drained after watching it. Which, for me, feeling something so powerful is a sign of a fantastic movie experience. If you have the opportunity, I recommend seeing it in IMAX. The expansive space, planet, and landscape shots make the experience well worth the added money. It is almost a cliché description, but I can't think of any other way to describe Interstellar other than...breathtaking.

9 Reels Out of 10

Filme épico de ficção científica! Excelente direção, efeitos especiais, trilha sonora, fotografia, roteiro... filme fechado 100%, com uma história bem envolvente e com um ritmo muito bom que te faz pensar em várias situações que são apresentadas no decorrer do filme. Explorar alguns dos conceitos mais "hardcores" da ficção científica como viagens espaciais interestelares, viagem no tempo, buraco de minhoca (espacial) e etc. As referências e homenagens a '2001' ficam bem claras e as comparações, em várias passagens, são inevitáveis. Entretanto, não se trata de uma cópia barata e sim de um grande filme com a mesma linha do '2001'. Com certeza não é o tipo de filme que vai agradar a todos, entretanto, se você é fã de ficção científica, se você assim como eu considera '2001: Uma Odisseia no Espaço' um dos melhores filmes da história do cinema, ou se você simplesmente gosta de apreciar uma grande produção, um excelente filme muito bem feito, eu indico 100% esse filme!!! Se não o melhor, com  certeza, um dos melhores filmes de 2014!!

So I'm going to split the potential audience here into two groups: those who thought Inception was one of the greatest films ever made and; those who thought Inception was good, but perhaps a tad overrated.

For those who believe that Inception is one of the top five films ever, Interstellar will be up there for you too.  Nolan again demonstrates his unique ability to discuss complex subject matter, and simultaneously build a powerful narrative that can engage all audiences.  The complexity actually goes up a notch from Inception, and despite trying to make it as simple as possible for laymans, bringing along a mate with a Phd in Astrophysics will certainly help.

For those who simply saw Inception as a 'good film', Interstellar will again rank as a 'good film'.  This takes nothing away from the brilliance of the subject matter, in building a thought provoking discussion.  In some ways, I feel that this could have been built as a trilogy, which would have allowed for more self contained narrative structures, in a similar way to what Gravity achieved.

Regardless, if only for the intellectual thought process behind it, you should watch this movie.  :)

This is a specific type of sci-fi film.  One that merges painfully grounded science with...well, have you seen the end of 2001: A Space Odyssey?  It's very clearly inspired by 2001, so your opinion on that one is a decent chart of how you'll feel about Interstellar.
Personally, I'm sort of split.  It's certainly a well-made film; the imagery is stunning and at times awe-inspiring, the performances are excellent (especially by McConoughy, who is proving himself as an actor with surprising force lately), and Nolan's tension filled hyper-real scenarios are as effective as ever.
Still, it's a flawed film, especially if you're not usually into this sort of thing.  The science jargon can become exhausting, and around the third act the film starts to overstay its welcome.  Additionally, for as much as they over-explain things, there's a surprising lack of clarity in the story quite frequently.
This isn't Nolan's best film, not by a long shot.  It is beautiful to look at, and has enough emotional investment towards the characters to carry us through; but it's overlong and overcomplicated.  I liked it well enough, especially when it addressed the complicated nature of aging in space (something rarely shown in fiction).  It's an okay film that overreached its grasp.

Interstellar was amazing. The science behind it made me wish I'd completed that astrophysics degree I started all those years ago. The story was clever, thought-provoking and, for me at least, easy enough to follow unlike its oft-compared film by the same director, Inception.

As with any movie that involves bending time, it starts getting a little wonky at the end (how many versions of a single "me" can there be?), but I have no doubt those are questions that were long considered by the writers. 

So that leaves the only other flaw as Anne Hathaway's character's seemingly pointless dialogue in the middle of the film about love being effectively "the fifth dimension". As soon as she started on about this, I was thinking "bleurghhh, stop talking, you're ruining the movie". Luckily McConaghy's character thought much the same thing and quickly cut her off.

Movies that make me think are my favourite movies. This kept me thinking all the way through and for hours afterwards, including some probably valuable self-reflection.

This movie according to me is at the level of inspiration as 'The Shawshank Redemption'. It has a beautiful story and with all honesty, is something 'Gravity' will never be. Also don't trust what critics say about this movie. They seem to think that if one doesn't understand a film, its bad. Quality entertainment, touching and visually spectacular. It makes you think beyond what any other movie will. A movie one simply has to watch. It's a rollercoaster ride that will leave you breathless and charged with so many emotions you wont stop talking about the movie for at least a day. Also, if you're  not familiar with relativity, quantum mechanics, time, etc. not to worry. This is a true visual marvel of a movie - a cinematic triumph packed with absolutely stunning cinematography and vast and overwhelmingly expansive landscapes contrasted with the intimate earth-bound drama. This is both Nolan's most ambitious and, for my liking, most effective movie - save for a few faults.

Okay, the dialogue is shockingly bad in parts (particularly everything spoken about love), Hans Zimmer's score was a bit too intrusive and not engaging enough for my liking and my dislike for Anne Hathaway showed no sign of stopping throughout Interstellar. These would usually bring a movie down to around 3* and less but Interstellar is an exception - its sheer ambition outweighs its faults as it proves itself to be a high grossing box office hit with unusual heart and undeniable visual beauty.

I have to say, I had pretty heightened hopes going into seeing this film. Those hopes were there for many reasons. Here are a few:

It's the first big sci-fi film to hit theaters since Elysium, and that was several years ago.
It's a Christopher Nolan film.
It's the next film in the Matthew McConaughey McConaissance, following Mud, Dallas Buyers Club, True Detective and The Wolf of Wall Street. All of which were great, and you should check them out if you haven't had a chance to yet.
The cast in general. Not only do you have McConaughey, but there's also Anne Hathaway, Jessica Chastain, Michael Caine, and the creepy guy from American Beauty (the boyfriend who video taped the plastic bag blowing in the wind).
So, as you can see, I had pretty high expectations going in. This film was going to change sci-fi cinema for me. Well, the question you're probably asking yourself right now is: "Did it?" And the answer to that is: "Well, yeah. I think it did."

Now before you go saying that I said Interstellar is the best movie ever, let me go a little more into detail in what I mean when I say "I think it kinda changed sci-fi cinema," what I'm really saying is, "it might change sci-fi cinema." Or more accurately, it might renew an appreciation for a long lost genre. Because when viewed by anyone who's seen 2001: A Space Odyssey, or Sphere, or Sunshine, or The Thirteenth Floor or Dark City, it becomes clear that this film is following the classic conventions of sci-fi, and it's doing a great job. There's scientist on a mission to save a dying planet, there's robots with personalities, there's dangerous foreign environments, there's science talk of black holes and relativity--which Neil deGrasse Tyson has said the film "Let's you experience [it] like no film has before." (in the movie relativity works as a  sort of unwanted time travel, people on Earth age faster than the people on the ship when they embark on certain planets in another galaxy). So all the things we want in an epic sci-fi film are here, and the best part is, Nolan makes it feel believable. He grounds the film in the father-daughter relationship, it's what becomes the heart of this movie.

My hope is that Interstellar will inspire other writers and directors to tackle the sci-fi genre with more vigor than just another post apocalyptic film starring 20 somethings as 17 somethings. After all, the working world is populated by adults, we deserve some adult movies, and this my friends, I am happy to report, is an adult movie. It's a must see. Get out there and get your ticket. But stay home if you hate robots and space ships. You'll find Katniss next door.

Wow! Interstellar is an incredible odyssey that takes off, goes boldly into new territories, and never lets up! Astonishing and daring, it boldly goes where no sci-fi flick has gone before.

Earth is ravaged by dust storms. Food and resources are limited. Our American Everyman, played convincingly by Matthew McConaughey, stumbles his way into a research facility and onboard a mission to venture out into the universe in the hopes of finding worlds that can sustain life. But time is limited. Choices must be made. Everything is at risk. Can he succeed in this mission? Can he also find his way back home? How will things pan out in the far reaches of space?

I admire Christopher Nolan for his efforts in keeping the intellectual mind, emotional heart, and adventurous spirit of film alive, which really shows here. Breathtaking visuals and interesting staging bring a visceral experience you don't want to miss, further elevated by a transcendent score from Hans Zimmer. The main principals perform commendably in fleshing out their characters. Entertainment is delivered with aplomb, providing its chuckles, thrills, chills, and awe-inspiring moments. Deeper themes are also discovered within this cinematic realm. I personally think the film works on numerous levels, whether it's a search for hope, a pondering of faith and logic, an exploration of the human condition, or a study of choices and bonds. Many surprises arrive, bound to bring genuine ubiquity to the table as well as support its ambition to be a true venture into the unknown.

However, the film struggles from its emotional detachment. A degree of this is necessary in order to be consistent with the transcendentalist tone set here. However, it's in full tilt, which makes us feel less invested in the characters than in the mechanics of the ride. This also comes at the expense of a daddy-daughter relationship that is integral to the core of the film. There's also a sense of heavy-handedness within this film, making the soft moments extremely soft that it's hard of hearing and banging very hard and loud on the cannons when the film puts us in enthralling situations. A little extreme, eh?

Just for the experience alone, it shoots up to being one of the greatest films of the year as well as one of the greatest cinematic accomplishments of our time...

O melhor do argumento dos irmãos Nolan: a tentativa de voltar a inflamar a centelha pioneira que se apagou na humanidade, apelar ao esforço colectivo que quase desapareceu depois de décadas de erros (colectivos). 

O abstraccionismo frio mas demolidor de Kubrick em 2001 foi necessário para uma época, tal como agora é necessário uma teia narrativa inspiradora, com bases científicas sólidas, para abanar o colectivo pioneiro entorpecido.

É só um filme, com limitações mas encerra uma grande homenagem, tudo continua a ser feito por Nolan e a sua equipa de forma manual, tal como fez o artesão Kubrick. Neste filme não há cenários verdes. 

Importa, ainda, destacar o trabalho do físico Kip Thorne e dizer que dentro do universo sci-fi, olhando para o que  foi produzido nos últimos anos, este filme é, sem dúvida, um 9/10, nem que seja pela ousadia de tentar inspirar as gerações mais jovens. Porque não um 10? Porque falta meia hora ao filme, para que a narrativa tenha tempo para respirar.

Christopher Nolan has built a strong reputation in the industry as one of its finest directors, having proven himself time and again on films such as the 'Dark Knight' trilogy and 'Inception.' He uses his tried and true approach on the marathon intergalactic drama 'Interstellar,' achieving mixed results. 'Interstellar' begins in the not too distant future, when famine and dust storms are widespread and it's clear humanity as we know it is quickly ceasing to exist. The story revolves around a pilot-turned-farmer named Cooper (played by Matthew McConaughey) who is recruited by genius Professor Brand (Michael Caine), who heads up a secretive NASA to leave his two young children to go on a mission to a far away galaxy in search of an Earth-like planet that could serve as a second home for the human race.

The gravity of the plot is enough to suck people into 'Interstellar,' but it's not enough to keep them engaged throughout the 169-minute runtime. Sure, there are plenty of action-packed sequences that come with any space journey, from near-death experiences on waterlogged and frozen wasteland planets to just the sheer challenge of surviving with other people along the way. On the acting front, McConaughey does reasonably well despite his mumbling stumbling southern drawl, and Anne Hathaway's no-nonsense Dr. Brand makes for a good character onscreen. Perhaps the best performance comes from Jessica Chastain, whose portrayal of There are also a host of familiar faces in minor roles, from John Lithgow to Ellen Burstyn and William Devane to Topher Grace, plus an unexpected Matt Damon sighting.

Of course, acting is not everything. 'Interstellar' suffers from long, drawn out scenes that could easily be condensed, and while there is definitely an element of mind-bending scenarios explored, some of the things that unfold as part of the story are too much to take in. Despite these missteps, 'Interstellar' does boast some quality CGI, which should not go unnoticed.

While it does not quite live up to its massive expectations, 'Interstellar' gives audiences a lot to think about long after the credits roll.

Of the films this fall, the one people seem to be most excited about is Interstellar. Not a big surprise: Christopher Nolan has ripped the big-budget filmmaking championship belt away from Steven Spielberg since the start of the new millennium, peaking with the Dark Knight/Inception. Interstellar, like Nolan's second tier efforts, is breathtaking to look at, and just misses its high due to holes in the story's foundation. I mean, I like Matthew McConaughey, but I can't believe he'd be a NASA pilot.

In some unspecified part of the future, a blight has slowly been destroying the crops on Earth. The earth is dying, including for farmers  Cooper (McConaughey), dad Donald (John Lithgow), Coop's son Tom (Timothee Calamet), and daughter Murph (Mackenzie Foy). Donald and Tom are resigned to their fate, but Cooper and Murph are dreamers, believing in ghosts and space. One night, the pair happenstance on a NASA project led by Cooper's old mentor, Professor Brand (Michael Caine). With the Earth dying, NASA found 3 worlds through a wormhole, and wants Cooper to fly the mission with other crew members Romilly (David Gyasi), Doyle (Wes Bentley), and Brand (Anne Hathaway), the Professor's daughter. Cooper decides to pilot the mission, leaving his kids behind, knowing that wormhole science could mean age acceleration for Earth and possibly missing his kids growing up.

Interstellar unapologetically references 2001: A Space Odyssey. It wants to be considered THAT good among the sci-fi elite. The movie's story is the weak link. It does have some parts that get it in the vicinity, especially grounding the space story in real pathos. The Cooper/Murph relationship is set up very nicely, with Murph clearly seeing her father as a hero and her best friend. The wormholes distort time in a way the audience can understand (Event Horizon can sue for a shot by shot remake), and the effect of the time warping are rapid and emotionally jarring. The hour or so build up to Cooper's fateful decision makes the separation painful and real. However, as the movie enters the wormhole, the plot is stuck between two worlds. It never quite builds successfully upon the effects of the Murph/Coop split until too late, and the space relationships were clearly left on the cutting floor to keep the running time below 3 hours, truncating any emotional effectiveness. As such, any parallels between humanity and science and space travel feel unearned, forcing Interstellar's science under the critical microscope, which will Neil DeGrasse Tyson will rip to shreds. Interstellar gets its main relationship right, and coasts on awesome special effects to cover up its logic leaps.

Interstellar needs to be seen in the theater, preferably IMAX. The space travel is a spectacular creation. Nolan built several machines to simulate spaceflight without a green screen. The first images of the spacecraft passing Saturn are breathtaking in scope. The wormhole flight is pretty intense and Kubrickian. Ever wonder what a giant tidal wave looks like?  You won't anymore. Nolan even works a black hole into the proceedings. Each world is milked for maximum grandeur in either beauty or inhospitability.  Nolan is one of the best at getting an audience to marvel at the wonders he gives life, then unleashes them on the main characters. The director knows how to milk something as simple as a space station docking for maximum dramatic effect.

Matthew McConaughey finally got to save the human race; good for him. His performance here has been described by others as a glue for the story as a whole, an apt description. McConaughey gets the audience to buy in on the pain of leaving his family and how every lost second weighs on him. This pain propels him forward to get the job done and keeps people riveted to the screen. There's lots of talent on screen here supporting the chill Texan - Anne Hathaway, Michael Caine, Jessica Chastain, Casey Affleck, John Lithgow, David Gyasi, and Wes Bentley (plus a fun secret). All of the actors on hand give their all, but the big key here is Mackenzie Foy, who has about an hour to sell how much she loves her father before they get ripped apart, and then sell the pain and anger towards him. Foy delivers in all of her scenes with the Oscar winner; although it's easy to get the audience on your side of you're a sad little girl, Foy sells love and sadness better than Anne Hathaway and Michael Caine here.

I really wanted Interstellar to be my 2001. I like the Kubrick film, but it has too many flaws for me to put it among the elite. Nolan will have to settle, like 2001 for me, to be a stellarly crafted visual masterpiece with a story in need of another draft. We now know that Alfonso Cuaron + Sandra Bullock is greater than Christopher Nolan + Matthew McConaughey.

interstellar, was far from stellar, but it was still good! very good, interstellar had an amazing story, i loved it. i also loved matthew mcconaughey and a breakthrough performance from his young daughter, along with the older version of his daughter, played from jessica chastain which was very surprising and really well done and a great, small unexpected character in a supporting role from matt damon he also did a pretty good job also. the score was amazing, suited the film excellently and the visual effects were pheonominal and honestly the most impressive sound and video technology i have experienced in a film EVER! HOW EVER! There are alot of flaws with the movie. What really bummed me out is the fact that it is such a good film, almost perfect up untill about 1hr 20 mins into the film. it gets alot more boring, and poluted with very complex science but like i said Matt Damon performs a great role, and i really liked him, but then he died, and that chapter of the movie was over, and that was a great chapter of interstellar. also after that, matthews kids start getting more involved with the plot, and this is the worst part about the movie, i hated casey afflecks character and his whole family which is his wife, and son. i hate them all, didnt make himself and his family better for the audience. jessica chastain was a great casting choice, and has a breakthrough performance, but her man in the film, played by topher grace is so boring, dull, horribly acted, useless and just strait up cringe worthy in everything he does, im surprised he is in a Nolan film. cant stand him. but this films twist redeems the whole movie. the last 40 minutes of the film is so amazing! and it was my favorite part about the film. its kind of heartfelt, and i really enjoyed the way nolan and the writers really handled the ending. but i was expecting alot more from this film, kind of disapointed, but i really thought that matthew should have gotten an oscar for this role, he was amazing and played the role perfectly, the oscars really snubbed him, i dont get why. check out interstellar if you already havent, its worth a watch

As a whole, I think this is one of Nolan's weaker films. That said, in my view Nolan has never made anything approaching a bad film so that isn't meant as an insult. Interstellar contains amazing performances, a riveting score by Zimmer, and some of the greatest space sequences ever put to film with jaw dropping cinematography. On a technical level this movie is a masterpiece, the real science behind the sci-fi makes this a future that seems truly plausible. For me it's the story that doesn't fully rise to the high level of the rest of the film, the narrative doesn't flow smoothly (pacing might gave been improved by leaving another 20+ minutes on the editing floor) and I've always found the end a bit jarring. Still, I have great respect for Nolan's ambition and Interstellar is well worth your time. Watch this on the biggest screen with the highest quality you can find and be prepared to be awed with the beauty of space

Interstellar is an easy target to both praise and/or pick apart, as has been done ad nauseam since its release. It's one of the most ambitious undertakings in recent memory, and sometimes that ambition gets in its own way. It starts off slow, the last 10 minutes are kind of wishy-washy, there are several plot holes and underwritten characters, etc., and yet it was an experience unlike any other I have seen, magnified by a 94-foot screen and booming sound system. There's a profound beauty to Interstellar that is literally out of this world that is hard to describe to someone who hasn't seen it. Nolan pairs the breathtaking visuals with hard sci-fi talk of wormholes, fifth dimensions and such, along with his humanistic philosophies involving mankind's continuing evolution and quest for love, which never quite fully connect together but certainly offers plenty to chew on. Meanwhile, Matthew McConaughey makes for a solid anchor on our journey into the beyond and back. Nolan aims for the stars on Interstellar, and though he may not reach them, he comes close.

One of the top 5 films I've ever seen. Mindboggling. Emotional. Astonishing. If you are a negative nitpicker of scientific facts you will only ruin your viewing experience of this gem of a film. With that, the facts are real, spacetime is related to gravity and the universe is a very complex thing we almost have no essential knowledge of (at this stage in the evolution of science). For all those nitpicking "scientists" hating on this film, I bet their great grandchildren will disagree with them. This film is so realistic, scientifically and spiritually astonishing, and it does it in such an emotionally relatable way.

As the movie progresses, more and more scientific theories pertaining to space travel are presented. Sometimes, the film struggles with combining realism and teaching complex topics to the layman. But the fact that this film challenges an audience to learn about subtleties of gravity, black holes, relativity,  and Murphy's Law whilst combining the human element of love, and pulls it off, is an amazing feat. As if that's not enough, the film adds a splash of sending a message to the world as well: We need to keep exploring and reaching. The acting and effects are just the tip of the iceberg for this film, and that says a lot.

"Interstellar" is the only Christopher Nolan movie I've liked since "Memento."  This sprawling space and time saga is set in the nearly apocalyptic future where food is scarce, farming is an essential though still blue-collar career, NASA has become SNASA (Secret NASA), and the smoonlanding (secret moonlanding) is thought to have been faked.  Cooper is an aeronautical pilot tapped for a dangerous mission of indefinite duration to find new life-sustaining planets.  His young daughter never quite forgives him for leaving, and his quest is one of survival and return.  

I especially love the scene of Coop driving away in a cloud of dust, underscored by the space shuttle countdown.  Mackenzie Foy as young Murph is sweet and teary, and Jessica Chastain deftly takes her into adulthood as a tough yet tender space crusader.  Surprise Matt Damon (the best kind of Matt Damon) is tender and menacing as the "destroyer of worlds" - a recurring motif that I enjoy in Nolan's work.  

The movie has its nonsensical flaws, of course.  Wes Bentley's character is killed off way to quickly and anticlimactically because emotional plot point.  The one equation to save humanity is a mere deus ex machina McGuffin.  It's not explained in any plausible, scientific manner; we just have to roll with it. And dat Anne Hathaway doe.  So melt-your-face-off-brilliant in "Les Miserables," yet so full of nothing in this.  Dr. Brand has gumption written into her, but Hathaway can't infuse enough life into a character with no compelling purpose or motivation beyond blah-blah-save-the-human-race-blah-blah-love-conquers-all.
