Don't watch this movie if you're not remotely into science (I hear there's a new fast and the furious for y'all). But for those of us into that kind of thing, Interstellar tastefully leverages experimentally verified science (like relativity) and theoretical science (like wormholes) to tell a story about people and what it means to be human.

I also liked:
* The robots. One of my favorite depictions of a working relationship between capable AI and humans. Also, great comedic relief
* Depiction of future technology. Seemed like the movie was set towards the end of the 21st century. The tech was progressive, but seemed attainable 60 years from now, even for a somewhat apocalyptic society.
* Theme of the supernatural just being something natural that you don't understand.
* Visuals. But I don't think anyone disagrees on this point.

This is the kind of intellectually stimulating, thought provoking, visually stunning, auditorially pleasing movies that sci-if lovers are blessed with once in a decade or more. It should be said upfront that: 1) this is not a flick, and likely won't be enjoyed by those who enjoyed, say, "Cloverfield"; 2) there is at least one point in the plot that requires some willful suspension of disbelief - but what sci-fi movie doesn't? This film is going to work your mind on multiple levels over the course of its nearly 3 hour runtime - from the problem solving to the science to the human elements of love and compassion. If we go to see movies to be moved by great stories of wonder involving great characters, this movie is worth every penny and then some. By now, it would be impossible to not consider Christopher Nolan one of the greatest filmmakers of all time.

Christopher Nolan's science fiction movie is big, ambitious, overblown, and full of fascinating ideas about the human condition, relativity, and quantum mechanics.  It must be said that a bundle of good ideas does not sustain a movie for almost three hours.  The film's extreme length allows for moments of melodrama and pointless exposition to seep into the narrative, which causes the picture to stall in the second half.  Nolan borrows heavily and unsuccessfully from the late Stanley Kubrick's 2001 masterpiece rather than etching out his own path.  

I'm not sure what has happened to Hans Zimmer, but his music score is aggravating as it strains for effect.  I had the same problem with his music to Inception.  One more technical point, the sound mixing to this movie was wildly uneven.  It was hard to hear certain lines of dialogue at different moments in the movie.  I've read other reviews that have mentioned the same thing.  Lastly, Matthew McConaughy is the reason to see this movie.  He keeps it afloat all by himself because his performance is first-rate and thoroughly heart-wrenching.  I bought the character's angst and arch all the way to the end.  He deserves an Oscar nomination for Best Actor.  I wanted to love Nolan's latest picture, but I came away unimpressed.  It is a mixed bag.

Entertaining, expertly made, and wrong. Its main value is that it is wrong - and so gives people a chance to consider the reality. If we manage to turn the whole earth into a dust bowl (not just big parts of it like now) then it will be more "Grapes of Wrath" than "Interstellar". Perhaps this can be sensed, because the film is rather creepy and the characters appear to be in a chronic state of depression. It is also a film that leaves you feeling depressed; it is an emotional ride in pursuit of a false hope. Most people would like to identify with those that are saved, but we know it would not be like that. In this film, being saved depends on love. Love changes everything, and even finds a new planet - in Hollywood, that is. The film toys with our real situation, and teaches that there is a second chance, even after everything, and your loved ones, are gone, something that we know we can't have. It does so very skilfully, so it should be approached with caution. A lot of people are seeing it. If only the same resources and talent had been put into a film to teach sustainability and equity. As it stands, the film is a spectacular advertisement for denuding the earth, leaving its silent, cooperative population to starve and perish, and launching a chosen few, suitably downbeat in style, and privileged in nature, onto a nice, clean new planet and an amazing, white picket fence space station, where they can play a nice, clean, white game of baseball.

Despite an ear-splitting soundtrack that often threatens to drown out important dialog, Interstellar is a profound hit, a love child of 2001: A Space Odyssey and Contact. Its effects are special, its casting top notch, and its meaning sufficiently ambiguous. In other words, this is a fairly typical Christopher Nolan movie.

In the movie, Earth is suffering through historic blight so bad that huge dust storms block out most sunlight and cause major breathing problems for the humans. (And probably the animals, too.) Such has been the sad state of affairs for some time; America in particular has become an agrarian society. Unfortunately, it's a failing society, and it's only a matter of time before the planet is uninhabitable by mankind.

Enter ex-scientist/pilot Coop (Matthew McConaughey) who's now a single dad raising two precocious kids along with his father in law. Through a series of plausible coincidences, Coop and his daughter Murphy stumble upon plans to send a manned mission to another galaxy by use of a wormhole - and those in charge want Coop to be the pilot. The idea is that the spacecraft Endurance, piloted by Coop, will fly through the wormhole and land on one or more of three potentially life-sustaining (according to data sent back by probes) planets. Once a suitable planet has been located, citizens of Earth will be transported via space stations - assuming NASA scientist Dr. Brand (Michael Caine) can solve the gravity-is-a-harsh-mistress problem.

Aboard the Endurance with Coop are scientists Amelia Brand (Anne Hathaway), Romily, and Doyle, along with robots TARS and CASE. That they do enter the wormhole and come out in a wholly different galaxy (the movie should have been called Intergalactic, right?) is not a spoiler. The trouble is that at least one of the three planet candidates is very close to a large black hole, ominously named Gargantua. What if this planet is the best alternative to Earth? Can't be safe to be so close to a black hole; luckily, the planet's mass is large enough to keep it from passing Gargantua's event horizon, so all is good. Well, good as I can make it without explaining what troubles Coop and crew run into, and that could ruin things for you, dear viewer.

It's possible some will find this movie to be a little overplotted (yet too vague), with a surfeit of exposition to help things along. This is necessary in part, though, because of two different timelines - that of Coop in the far-off galaxy and that of Murph back on Earth itself. And this is because of a time slip that Coop encounters that slows time for him relative to Earth time, to the tune of one outer-space minute equalling several years on Earth. 

Admittedly, there were moments when I felt like I'd missed something - that's attributable to how quickly Nolan propels the plot and to how damnably loud the soundtrack is at times. Hans Zimmer's score is excellent, but clearly someone figured that turning it up to 11 was the way to go. I mean, why allow an intricate plot get in the way of booming, sweeping sounds?

Also, like Kubrick's 2001, the final twenty minutes can be puzzling. There's not much more that can be said about this that won't reveal something important. I found it fascinating and satisfying and in keeping with the rest of the movie. Perhaps not all loose ends are tied up at the end, but I'm one of those who feels that's a good thing. 

Nolan's Interstellar is spectacle supported by solid science and a fertile imagination. If the Academy Awards included only five nominees for Best Picture, this film probably wouldn't make the cut - but it should be among the top ten for the year and thus earn such a nomination, along with some for sound and effects.

This is getting mixed reviews, and I completely understand why - it's long, it's serious, it's kind of confusing, it could be easily considered pretentious and it's also something of a throwback; possibly as close as this century has gotten to a Close Encounters or a 2001. As such, it's unabashedly right up my alley - it is thoughtful, adult sci-fi fused with weighty character drama, both visually unique and conceptually brain-frying. I've no idea how kindly repeat viewings will be to it, but today, I feel like Interstellar treated me like more of an intelligent adult than any other film I've seen for quite some time.

If you thought Inception was the most mind-boggling Christopher Nolan movie, wait until you see Interstellar. It makes your brains turn to soup and ooze out of your ears. But it's ok, because it's AMAZING. Definitely my favorite movie of the year so far. It's an emotional, dramatic, exciting, heart-pounding journey through the universe. The movie stars Matthew McConaughey as Cooper, a former military test pilot selected to lead an exploration mission to find earth a new home as it's slowly dying. The film costars Anne Hathaway, Michael Caine, Jennifer Chastain, and a high A-list Hollywood actor that is meant as a cameo but actually has a big role in the movie. I'm not saying who it is in case you want a surprise. But McConaughey gives a heartfelt performance that finally allows me to say he's a great actor after discovering his talent in last year's Dallas Buyers Club. But that aside, Interstellar has amazing visuals, dramatic performances, an exciting plot, great character development, superb directing from Christopher Nolan who happens to be my favorite filmmaker, and a pounding score from Hans Zimmer. Interstellar surprised me, is a great film, and I highly recommend checking it out, especially in IMAX.

Christopher Nolan shows us again that he's a cinematic genius. The plot is highly intelligent and imaginative, though it may disappoint those who are either not cosmologically well-read or those who are so well-read as to require a scientifically airtight script. Most importantly, it achieves the transcendent quality of a film that takes us where others have not yet taken us: to the edges of our scientific understandings and their interactions with real human beings.

Interstellar is an outstanding depiction of the unimaginable: finding inhabitability beyond planet earth. Set in the future, Matthew McConaughey leads a team of space researchers through a wormhole billions of light-years away to find the best of three possible planets that earth's civilisation could be transported to as a global Dust Bowl renders the earth unliveable. 

The film takes us on the space journey of a team of astronauts aiming to find a new inhabitable home and the difficulties that come along the way that pushes every astronaut to their highest limit - the possibility of never seeing their loved ones again. In an all-star Oscar-winning cast featuring Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, Matt Damon, Michael Caine and Ellen Burstyn, Interstellar aims to rectify the often too many bog-standard sci-fi flicks with a good, enticing story but terrible acting that have come to define the genre. 
 
What is rarely displayed in this picture is the personal side of science. The astronauts make the heartbreakingly difficult decision to pursue their mission compromising their chances of seeing their family. Science isn't as clear-cut, simple and fact-driven as we may think. We really empathise with the astronauts on their plight across our solar system.

It's disappointing to see Anne Hathaway cast in this picture. Honestly, she is perfectly nice to look at. But she really contributes nothing to this picture other than being the daughter of the intellectual mastermind heading the mission from earth. Her acting ability is unnatural and not appropriate in what is a very serious movie. I mean she has come so far in what a career can achieve from the Princess Diaries movies, but I could see any other actor taking her place in this movie. I would have liked to have seen Maggie Gyllenhaal take on the role of Brand. I believe she would have been able to demonstrate a degree of vulnerability and empathy we needed to feel for her character that Hathaway was unable to convey.

The standout performance of this picture is Jessica Chastain. She is more than just an example, she is a leader in never giving up on a career as a struggling artist whose perseverance and talent has prevailed through an industry that is, apparently, focused more on making money rather than nurturing talent. 

But what we all know that the 'McConnaissance' is in full swing. McConaughey is able to convey an allure of mystery and complexity required for such a character. Although I can't see McConaughey mastering comedic roles in the future (as we've seen from the unimaginative, predictable rom coms he starred in early in his career), he definitely nails these moody, disturbed and damaged characters in the last few years so well. 

Just to finish, I'm surprised this picture wasn't released in 3D. It's better than Gravity (both acting-wise and plot-wise) and the cinematic experience one can only imagine experienced of this movie in 3D in terms of time-shifting between galaxies and other worldly environments, 3D would, almost certainly, have created a unique viewing. I guess movie studios are really moving the motion picture industry in a new direction and Sci-Fi is back in fashion as we have seen in the high box office returns in Gravity and Interstellar and undoubtedly in the new Star Wars film next year.
Good movie! exactly what I expect from this director

Nolan's latest tackles thematic realms once explored by Stanley Kubrick. While Interstellar takes no shame in its influence from 2001 : A Space Odyssey (from narrative techniques and deliberate long shots to its score's hauntingly beautiful organ chords), it takes full advantage of modern sensibilities and hosts some spectacular deep-space thrills. What's more, as has been the case every time I've seen the man in a film thus far, it cements Matthew McConaughey as one of my favorite big stars working today.
I must admit, however, the film isn't quite perfect. There are a handful of moments where the acting just doesn't reach the emotional heights that the story deserves, and the technobabble (though probably much more scientifically-backed than, say, Wars or Trek) can drag to the point of tedium and convolution. The ending, which I won't spoil, may also divide viewers depending on their expectations, though I imagine, much like Inception, this film will reward repeat viewings.
This all said, and much to the filmmakers' credit, these nit-picky moments cannot take away from how masterful the film is on a technical level. The truly great scenes aren't just great, nor are they scarce; there are probably half a dozen sequences that, through a miraculous combination of sight and sound, literally made my jaw drop. Flipping trucks and explosions are cool, but they don't make you cry and contemplate your existence (..unless you really like flipping trucks...then again, I do live in a world where you can hear someone claim the human-to-wolf transformation in New Moon is "the most beautiful thing I've ever seen" the same year Avatar came out.....moving on). 
Interstellar amounts to a satisfying (if occasionally flawed) epic of adventure, sacrifice, and humanity's place in the universe, and its highpoints confirm the existence of something that I can only call pure cinema. 
See this in theaters. IMax if you can.

Much like Nolan's "Inception", "Interstellar" is full of bold, big ideas. And much like the former, his latest film also suffers from a disconnect between its heady ideas to the story's emotional facets (or lack thereof). This is the most cerebral of Nolan's films to date and whether the film's science he puts forward makes sense is another point of discussion. The film is so heavy handed in scientific concepts making it cold and calculating that it stunts any effort in achieving an emotional arc. Being heady and dense is fine for a literary experience but cinematically, it doesn't always work. To sum it up: "Interstellar" is all brain with no heart.

This film banks on two things:
1) That you are a Christopher Nolan fan.
2) That you really really really like science.

The new film from Christopher Nolan, the man behind the Dark Knight Trilogy, Inception and Memento brings us one of the BIGGEST space travel adventures ever committed to film. I really don't know how I can truly explain just how BIG I mean when I say BIGGEST, this film has pulled out all the stop with regards to size, scale and stakes.

Interstellar wears a lot of its influences with pride but it is when the drama and action kick into gear that is when Nolan pulls ahead of the pack by giving us large scale, all or nothing, do or die sequences. Whether it's a fist-fight on an icy planet, mid-space explosions or mountain-size tidal waves everything has been structured to make sure that you're not just on the edge of your seat but that you are holding your breath trying not to pass out from lack of oxygen.

The soundtrack, much like the rest of the film, borrows from other science-fiction
masterpieces and Hans Zimmer, as always, does an excellent job. The only real issue with the film though is the soundtrack. Often it is very overpowering and at times when important pieces of information are being delivered to the audience. Sometimes it was so loud that I could not hear what was being said and had no idea why a character was now doing what they were doing.

Well you may just have to overlook some rather clunky lines of dialogue ("Look Cooper, I screwed up. I'm sorry. But you knew about relativity" will stay with me for a while) but this is without doubt a very fine movie indeed. Actually a story of small, human interactions and relationships, Interstellar is played out against a proper Space Opera background. The plot unfolds slowly and deliberately, taking us from a small US farm during a major global crisis that threatens to doom the human race, out to a last ditch expedition to find a habitable planet. The thread that weaves this epic plot together is the story of Cooper, a one time test pilot, who has to make the agonising decision to abandon his family and home in order to try to save humanity. There's some forgivable pseudoscientific gobbledygook but Christopher Nolan manages to transcend this and carry the audience with him on this amazing voyage of discovery. There are some obvious comparisons to be made with 2001: A Space Odyssey and Nolan doesn't hide these or shy away from them. There are some nice nods to that film in both the concept and design. I did like for example, the realisation of the slab-like robots which hark back to 2001s monoliths. There's also the idea of unknown aliens trying to send a message to humanity. As with 2001, this is dealt with in a suitably cryptic manner which forms an important plot point. Special mention must also be made of the stunning soundtrack provided by Hans Zimmer. This is a fine example of the screen composers art and ably demonstrates what a master of this form Zimmer is. This movie won't be for everyone. There's no alien threat or rampaging monsters but rather it is a thought provoking fantasy about human endeavour and family bonds. I loved this film, feeling it more than lived up to the hype and it further demonstrates how good both Anne Hathaway and Matthew McConaughey in lead roles when given material that they can rise to.

A very important film in many ways that is also a spectacle for the eye to see. While it can be a bit long, it is more than rewarding.

I remember seeing Empire Strikes Back on a 70mm print when I was a kid.  I was a grand epic screening, even from the back row.  It was what going to the movies was about, the immersion in something so immense and powerful that when you left you almost felt a little smaller.  Likewise seeing Interstellar on 70mm real IMAX was something to behold.  The story was not nearly as good as Dark Knight or Inception, but it had its moments and the visual story was impressive.  At times a little overpowering with music to tell us how we should be feeling, but at the same time, it was hard not to get caught up in it all.  Watching something like this on a TV at home would be as sacrilegious as watching a pan-n-scan version of Gone With The Wind.

Interstellar is visually breathtaking, masterfully acted, and a work a theatrical art. However, a painfully predictable plot combined with a few too many overdrawn moments prevents Interstellar from transcending goodness to greatness. The film's greatest moments of inspiration are found early, but quickly fade into generic and hackneyed sci-fi humdrum. As all the film's mystique seems lost, the finale attempts - with slight success - to bring back the awe and wonderment. The climax also brings a long overdue "reveal" which many viewers will have already figured out. This reveal is further drawn out by a borderline insulting play-by-play explanation unfit for a film attempting to be an intellectual journey. Interstellar finds itself hindered by its own ambitions. Falling short of high-brow and too complex to be considered mindless fun; Interstellar digs itself into a pit of displacement. Despite being top heavy and lengthy, Interstellar is still an exciting, entertaining, and breathtaking spectacle worth watching at least once.

Christopher Nolan has, miraculously, done it again. Another visually resplendent masterpiece which may not be his strongest film to date, but it is definitely one of the best science fiction films of the decade thus far (up there with "Gravity").

"Interstellar" tells the story of a post-apocalyptic Earth, where food have become a scarcity, resulting in wars, population decrease and a general drop in way of life. When Cooper and Murphy start digging around a strange occurrence in their room, they come to a secret base holding the might of NASA. Cooper then ends up piloting a dangerous mission to find a new suitable planet for the inhabitants of planet Earth to occupy as their own homeworld slowly dies.

The film has a typically star-studded cast that includes a mixture of new faces and Nolan regulars. This cast includes Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, Jessica Chastain, Michael Caine, Casey Affleck, Wes Bentley, Matt Damon, John Lithgow, Topher Grace and David Oyelowo. This cast, despite often being required to speak some convincing technobabble, eases into some often deep chararacters quite comfortably and make quite an unimaginable story feel so plausible.

Helping the plausibility is the involvement of astrophysicist and author Kip Thorne as a scientific consultant. The film covers a lot of quite heady science, including wormholes, black holes, time distortion, general relativity, gravitational pull and 5-dimensional universes. In many movies, these films could be raised in a manner that would only confuse any but the most educated audiences, but Interstellar is able to accurately portray them while keeping the plot accessible to a layman audience.

The only issue I had with this film was some of the sound mixing. Supposedly, Nolan did this on purpose to accurately portray life in space, but it does, in my view, occasionally your mind out of the Interstellar world as you wonder whether the cinema/your home sound system has developed a fault.

A brilliant space film. 9/10.

This is a movie that I've been wanting someone to make for a long time.  I've always loved the ending of 2001: A Space Odyssey.  I love those open endings that leave you thinking.  Nolan has won me over with Interstellar.  Such a beautiful love song to 2001: A Space Odyssey ... A perfect companion.  The premise is simple enough.  What lies beyond our known dimensions?  As a human race, we are explorers.  Film is the perfect medium to imagine and explore such a question.  The knocks against the film are mainly film structure subjectiveness.  How anyone can tell such a broad and big idea and make it accessible to general audiences is an extremely difficult challenge.  I accept some of the needed contrived story devices, as it felt like a privilege to take a wondrous ride into the unknown.  Thank you Mr. Nolan ... Damn, it was such a good film!

I'm speechless.
I knew what to expect from Nolan, who has been steadily increasing his repertoire for almost two decades. Each film outdoes his last and builds on the already mind blowing pieces that have gone before it. From The Following to Memento to The Prestige to Inception, how would he outdo himself this time?
All I can say (without giving too much away) is that he finds a way to make something incredible almost plausible. Something disjointed almost cyclical. And he managed to do so with a power and emotion that I rarely see in movies. You'll laugh, you'll cry (a lot), and you'll get to the end of the three hours and finally gasp for breath.
The dynamics of space are hard to explain, Interstellar is hard to explain. But oh boy does it pay off!

Anne Hathaway is also very strong, and Mackenzie Foy who plays his daughter gives a really strong and emotional performance as his young daughter. The visuals are mesmerizing. When Saturn appears on screen it's breathtaking. Hans Zimmer's score is also masterful. The music is so powerful and it really helps move the movie along. I loved this movie. It's a movie that I think many can enjoy. The best movie of the year (so far)

"WOW", "What just happened", "Mind blown". These are just some of the many phrases that came out of people's mouths after watching the movie Interstellar. Oscar nominated 3 times, Christopher Nolan, did an amazing job yet once again. Interstellar truly did live up to the standards and as always Christopher Nolan did not disappoint. This movie is not your average save the world find another planet kinda of movie. The movie plot was well thought out with an amazing storyline. if you have not seen this movie yet you must go see it now! it is truly mind-blowing. if you have seen Inception, another work by Christopher Nolan, then you must definitely watch this movie. 

The movie starts off with a single father ,who is a farmer, Cooper with his two children and his own father. Cooper, along with his daughter, stumble upon a secret meeting and cooper is sent off to rescue planet earth. in this film our planet is devastated with famine and it will not be long until everyone starts dying off. it is up to cooper and 3 other scientists to find a suitable planet for everyone on Earth to live. a return back home is not guaranteed which leaves cooper's daughter heartbroken. 
The casting for this movie was excellent. Matthew McConaughey  did an outstanding job and made every line believable. Mackenzie Foy did a great job as well. in this movie she played Murph the daughter of Cooper. Both her and McConaughey did a great job establishing a believable father-daughter relationship. 
The cinematography for this film was out of this world. Fun fact many people may not know is that this film was filmed not using any green screen at all. Christopher Nolan did an amazing job because instead of using green screens they used projectors to project onto walls so that the actors could actually feel and see what they had to put on a great act. This is not a surprise that the cinematography for Interstellar was very good just like it was with Inception.  The crazy flips and turns of the cameras and edits were unbelievable. The fact that green screens were not used definitely made this movie amazing and very believable. 
overall, Christopher Nolan did a great job yet again. You can not go wrong with a movie choice that Christopher has worked on. every minute of the movie was well paced and kept you on the edge of your seat. It was great that even though this movie is lengthy, it did not drag out.

Regardless, Nolan sticks with many of his trusted actors to pull this off and many of the creative decisions work really well to make this a truly well crafted film.

Christopher Nolan is the director responsible for two (or three, arguably) modern movie masterpieces: 'Momento' and 'The Dark Knight'. Some may want to count 'Inception' in that category, but I will take a pass. I will also pass on 'Interstellar' - but not for lack of trying. 
'Interstellar' does everything a blockbuster should do. It does everything a sci-fi action/thriller should do. It does everything a cerebral film should do. It just doesn't do ANY of the singular things exceptionally well to the point of groundbreaking (see, 'Avatar'). This movie checks of all the boxes of what makes a great movie, but doesn't take us to that next level of movie-watching.

The story is that Earth is literally dying, and this time there is no coming back from the brink. Humans must leave the planet. Enter a group of pioneers sent into space to journey through a found wormhole. I love the very idea of this premise, but 90% of everyone is already lost lol. And that is where 'Interstellar' falls a bit short. For a science guy like me, deep space explorations is no new frontier; one can watch any number of space documentaries  on Youtube in full HDwith impressive computer simulations - or, the one can watch the excellent revamped 'Cosmos' series starring top physicist Neil DeGrasse Tyson (my favorite scientist lol). These shows explore the concepts of wormholes and black holes - dark energy and dark matter on a daily basis.  Nolan's film does the same - but hey, we get to see and hear this all the time on the internet. The film version offers a heart-wrenching family narrative to go along with it.

The TRUE star of 'Interstellar' is science. Mainly, gravity. Deep space is a terrifying place! Our scope of knowledge pales the further out we go; and once Quantum Physics enters into the equation, we know NOTHING. The laws of physics - of time, of space, of...EVERYTHING, changes at the quantum level. And all of that apparently happens near black holes. Once the action gets near a black hole things get very bizarre. That is where the film truly 'shines' (pun intended lol).

 For a film this EPIC in its scope and presentation it REEEALLY needed to push the cinematic envelope. 'Interstellar' deserves as much credit for its space-time cosmic physics as it does for its seamless CGI. The space scenes (and sound effects, I might add) are breathtaking - BUT, truth be told I was more Floored and Stunned by the perilous beauty of 'Gravity' - and that took movie place a mere few miles from Earth! For a movie that literally FOLDS SPACETIME in half and travels to distance galaxies (and at one point traveling INTO A BLACK HOLE!) - .I was still a bit underwhelmed. Not saying it isn't impressive, but it didn't break any new movie ground. Not in the same vein as say 'The Matrix' did back in 1999. Or 'Jurassic Park'.  

From a critical point, the biggest slight against this movie was its tech-babble. Apparently people lose interest listening to how time bends and warps based on gravitational pull. I FIND THIS ALL FASCINATING! I actually enjoyed listening to the technicalities of interstellar travel - the effects of a giant black hole has on time as much as the next science lover. The REAL slight to this movie is that the general populace isn't nearly as scientifically literate as we SHOULD be - and that is a shame. Deep space travel is something that every developed nation on Earth should give credence to - a topic that came up in the movie.

The acting is effectively stirring and emotional. There are plenty of 'Oohs' and "Ahhs!'. A few plot twists. A sarcastic (and extremely resourceful) robot brings  surprising humor to the 'weight' of the movie (pun intended) - and a guest appearance by an A-list actor added a nice surprise. Christopher Nolan's career cache is so remarkable that we expect to be WOWED every time out. 

Overall,  'Interstellar' is a masterful movie. Just not a Masterpiece.
GRADE: B+

The earth is dying, with its soil no longer able to sustain crops other than corn and the extinction of humanity is imminent. Matthew McConaughey plays ex-NASA test pilot Cooper, a former astronaut and dedicated family man, especially toward his daughter Murphy (named after the Murphy's Law). He is invited by the (publicly) defunct NASA to find a new home, for they have found a wormhole near Saturn to another galaxy. And what follows shows many similar elements "2001: A Space Odyssey", not that this is a bad thing. The visuals in the film are simply majestic. It's a slow-burn of a film that will stay with you in contemplation of your place in the universe and time.

How good is a movie that makes no sense?  Isn't that sort of  ... essential to a good plot?  The physics is nonsense and we're back to the same time paradox: if the present contains immediate doom, the future cannot go back and save it, because there IS no future. Hello.  

That said, Ann Hathaway and Matthew M are both gorgeous, the crappy plot isn't their fault, it's extremely loud and big, with a lot of machines that blink and a funny robot.  Hence three stars.

And that's a damn shame with a cast like this. Especially sitting in a theater for three hours. I didn't bother to do the research on what I'd just watched. That would have been another three hours at least.
I enjoyed this movie much more than I thought I would. It made me think and sparked interesting conversations with my husband; which are my favorite types of qualities in movies. I'd recommend it.
A mind-blowing experience that demonstrates the best that modern film-making has to offer.
Amazing movie. definitely one of the most original plots I have seen in a long time

"Interstellar" 10 Scale Rating: 7.0 (Good) ...

The Good: At times, the film is gripping and borders on epic. The characters are well written and fleshed out. McConaughey turns in one of the best performances that I have ever seen him give and his supporting cast (Hathaway, Caine, Affleck, Chastain, Bentley, and Damon) are also superb. The scientific aspects are fascinating and the science geek in me was very entertained for stretches. Nolan's depiction of the fall of humanity feels realistic (even if it's a tad preposterous) and hits home. Also, as McConaughey drifts further and further away from his family, you feel it. Well done, for the most part.

The Bad: At just under three hours, the film is too long. I personally don't usually mind lengthy films, but at times it feels drawn out for the sake of drawing it out ... especially near the end. Eventually, all the bad luck that the crew faces starts to wear on you. It feels near constant and also puts them in situations that they get out of by performing impossible feats or suddenly have a stroke of good luck instead. Lastly, the technical aspects will lose some. While I enjoy hearing people chat about time/space distortion, relativity, event horizons, and quantum physics ... I can only listen to so much of it and can't imagine how someone who ISN'T interested in those subjects would feel.

Interstellar is very well made and acted, and I was hoping to be a fan. Unfortunately  Christopher Nolan has made one of my cardinal sins of filmmaking: the characters are emotionally immature and the whole expedition comes across extremely unprofessional. In this millennium do we still buy that saving humankind only takes a less-than-handful of I'll-prepared renegades? I was hoping to be well beyond Total Recall territory by now.

Interstellar is like Gravity, but there's actually something happening. There, I said it. It's definitely touching. One way or another it will leave you thinking about life and how deep it can really be. I'm not completely sure why, but I'm told it's not 100% scientifically correct, which definitely costs some points to a movie which tryed to explain  every detail of  the context. The obvious flaw this movie has though is that it's too goddamned long. In a part where they say 23 years have passed, damn, it sure felt that way. If you're kinda sleepy it's definitely gonna knock you out.

Man. Even more ambitious than I assumed it would be, if that's even possible. Incredible action scenes with a score that just ratchets it up an order of magnitude in drama - perfectly deployed score. Unfortunately, as is often the case with such huge efforts (for instance, Nolan's own The Prestige), the most important thing is the story is the weakest link. There are other things that can be nitpicked, sure. The huge reveal in the story is very telegraphed, it's slow-starting, the themes are stated really obviously through dialogue, there's a long section where the story seems to be falling apart. A couple of really huge physics plot holes. Does it suck? Of course not. It's awesome. But it's also not the greatest story ever told, though it is clearly trying to be. One pleasant surprise in this is Hathaway. I thought she would stick out like a sore thumb in a bad way, and she completely nails her role. This is a supreme case of a director going for the jugular and cramming a ton of intellect in, so it's really, really hard to distill into a review, but the basic point is, it's like The Fountain or Gravity, it's great because of its ambition, but unfortunately, it is also flawed because of that same ambition.
A little long but a visually stunning movie.   Love the robots in this movie.

I see the audience score is higher than the Tomatometer and that is hardly surprising as this is a film set to divide opinion. I think it is brilliant, supremely well made with a uniformly strong cast. I think people are trying too hard in trying to connect the dots logically and scientifically rather than going with what Christopher Nolan has supplied a deeply personal story about love and family. The effects are top notch and believable, it's good to see a film maker presenting space as a vacuum in which there is no noise outside the craft. Did I already say I think its brilliant?
Nolan is the master of creating all-time masterpieces.

Christopher Nolan guns to out-2001 2001, and (a bit unfortunately) to out-Contact Contact. To my considerable surprise, I feel as though he may have succeeded. This movie is one of grandiose scope, pitting the immensity of concepts like human extinction against deeply personal, intimate characterization carried by solid performances (with the odd exception of an inexplicably lazy and mumbling Michael Caine). The sense of stake and scope in this film is perpetual, with themes of loss, personal sacrifice, and the incredible risks at stake hanging over the proceedings like a funeral shroud for humanity. The scenic tension is amplified by excellent visual effects, a haunting and moving instrumental score, and interplay between both personal and macroscopic human affairs. It's a story of humanity clinging to survival by its very fingertips, and feels that way throughout. There is one unfortunate break in this tension, however: The film's gross misstep in making it clear that the matter is already settled. The use of "documentary interview style" footage near the beginning makes it clear, within the first handful of scenes, that everything works out, and it leaks the sense of anxiety like a crack in a space helmet. Even with this factored in, I still found myself strangely unsure, not quite able to fully invest faith that things would turn out all right when so much was going wrong.  Unfortunately, for a viewer less  caught up in the tone, this ambiguity isn't as likely to take hold. Nor are several science fiction cliches that are about as subtle and unpredictable as a landing strip. That said, the moving and human heart of the film, while treading at times into mawkishness, forms a strong foundation.

Christopher is doing a classic movie here. (Perhaps you might say timeless?)

First of all, I want to mention I don't like science fiction movies. I usually stay away from big blockbusters, too. I prefer independent movies that are character driven with excellent dialog. Another thing...I have never put my phone on vibrate and texted-even once-in ANY movie. Until this one! 

At the one hour and 45 minute mark of this movie I started texting my daughter. This was our conversation. Me:  We are at the movie Interstellar. It;s boring and stupid and depressing. I guess you have to love sci-fi. Your dad looks engrossed. yuck! Me (again): And just when I thought it couldn't become less believable! Me (again): It has become ridiculous! My daughter:  Hahahaha MY mom. Texting during a movie? It must be bad! Me: Right-you laugh while I sit HERE on my birthday! (YES-it WAS my birthday!) My daughter: Hahahaha  Me: In th dark! This might be the most nonsensical movie I have ever seen and it started around 5:30. When WILL it end??? Me (again) And now they are going for the kill the puppy ending? My daughter: Hahaha Happy Birthday, I love you! Is it over yet? Me (an eternity later) We are home. THANK GOD!!     

When I left the theater, after he shook his head over me texting during the movie, my husband pointed out to me that if had taken physics and understood it, that I would realize there was REAL science behind much of the movie. Ho Hum!

I do understand the sense and science behind climate change and I admitedly do NOT understand worm holes. And I sort of get the possibility of different dimensions in time and space. And I would have appreciated it more had I seen at on an Imax screen. Maybe. And the ending was more interesting than I expected.

Uncomfortably maudlin performances distract from an interesting theme and visually beautiful story, preventing you from suspending your disbelief.  I really, really looked forward to this movie, but we spent too much time with not enough plausible background in some future, dystopian Kansas. What felt like 40 minutes of preamble could have been condensed into a few minutes.  It felt like the director was telling the actors in each scene, "OK, this is your opportunity to ACT!!"  In a 2:40 movie putatively about interplanetary exploration we spent 5 minutes on one planet and 15 minutes on another, and we don't see the 3rd planet until the end credits roll?  When returning from the first planet, after losing a crew member on the exploration, the first thing the star does is sit down and review his accumulated personal messages from earth, tears streaming down his face.  "Yeah, we're back.  That planet, sucks.  Gimme a minute while I check my e-mail..."  Really? If we're counting on these marshmallows to save humanity, I give up.  Hello?!?! You are ASTRONAUTS...

 I do not understand how this movie seems to be well-received where Oblivion, a real classic, failed.  If you love McConaghey, save your money and watch True Detective.  If you love Anne Hathaway, why are you watching science fiction?

If you didn't pay attention in your Jr high science class, I insist that you either bring your encyclopedia with you to the theater or just hang on during this mind-blowing, Sci-Fi, action packed, thrill ride that is made of pure, climactic, imaginative scenes that are almost impossible to explain. It's another Christopher Nolan cinematic phenomenon, that just like the spinning totem in INCEPTION, leaves you theorizing for hours about the ending. Matthew McConaughey nails his performance as a former shuttle pilot who is sent on a classified mission to find life in another universe to save humanity. This movie has galactic effects similar to GRAVITY, an in-depth, layered story line like INCEPTION, a worldly, mankind-saving plot like ARMAGEDDON, & parallel time dilations that precisely make up the movie BUTTERFLY EFFECT. Nolan somehow was able to wrap all that up in one film, while also making the connection between physics & fate. This movie is an IMAX MUST SEE as he absolutely nails the realistic effects of space, extra dimensions, & gravity. I will not be ashamed to admit that, I too, will need to watch this movie at least once more to become only a smidge closer to understanding this 3-hour on-screen madness that consists of crazy twists & turns.

Beguiling visuals and an entrancing soundtrack from Hans Zimmer weren't enough to square the extreme cognitive dissonance provoked by a plot that's, well, ludicrous.

Drifting through wormholes, grazing the event horizon of black holes and experiencing the time warping effects of mega-gravity, I was entirely at ease. However the characters' behaviour, lurching from incoherent to plain dumb had me completely baffled.

Nolan asks his audience to accept that these space farers are the brightest and the best Mother Earth can produce. Yet they behave like total imbeciles at most every opportunity. 

Clearly the director has invested heavily in devising an expansive plot that explores some of the most awe inspiring implications of the laws of relativity and space travel. However the story and characters seem to have been sprinkled on top, long after the cake was baked. Like so many throw away films, almost every twist and turn is driven by a really smart person doing something really stupid.

After going to the extreme of making an astrophysicist co-executive producer, Nolan would have done better to recruit someone that understands something a little more down to earth - his characters.

This however isn't Nolan's worst sin. When it comes to getting a little carried away with his storylines the man has form. Would Batman really have hung up his cape because the Joker goaded him into it? Did Leonardo Di Caprio really need to go 7 levels down in Inception? In Interstellar Nolan drives right off the reservation. 

The result is a glorious, occasionally mesmerising, sometimes baffling, often ridiculous, disappointment.  

If you haven't seen it, you should go but when you get to the end sequence you'll know exactly what I'm talking about. One word - books. (You'll see)
it's not the best movie of 2014, but it is one of the best.

Robots and Wormholes and Love! Oh my! Believe it folks I finally saw Interstellar (2014)
The Good: This film is without a doubt the most beautiful, fantastic  looking spectacle I have seen this year. Everything from the grainy CINEMATOGRAPHY used in the beginning of the film; to the masterful shots of our vast and beautiful universe. The SOUND in the film is quite remarkable even though a couple of times it had small hints of Nolan's Inception. The CAST was ok, but no one; other than Mathew Mcconaughey, delivered a slamming of the dunking in their roles. The film moves at a fast pace in order to get to the good parts. Extremely difficult questions about life and the universe are tackled with satisfying answers. Oh and I almost forgot; The Robots are AMAZING!! I love that Nolan chose to have pragmatic robots for this universe. My favorite was TARS

The Bad: The film is far from perfect but its still going to fall in my top ten films of this year. I think the movies' fast pace is necessary because of it heavy themes but it is also to the film's detriment. Sometimes the pace of the film leaves too many plot holes; which at times affected the character relationships and the world building. 
CAST: i felt that Anne Hathaway had no place in this movie; in fact most of the well known faces kind of took me out of the film. 

The Ugly: There was nothing ugly about this film. that is all.

I Highly recommend this film despite all its flaws and Anne Hathaway!

Do you know what a worm hole is? I didn't. How could you travel light years from earth and still be alive. What would happen to those you left behind? This film is intellectually challenging, visually enthralling. The plot was vapid, the story line poorly edited, the characters unbelievable, but somehow I don't remember being bored.  
Matthew McConaughey gave it his all, but came off like a Hollywood cowboy instead of the greatest living astronaut. Anne Hathaway, still not sure what she was doing in this film playing the scientist's daughter .And Michael Caine, the scientist whose death bed confession made me say right out loud, "WHAT?" So the story was impossible and even a little goofey...But, somehow I don't remember being bored.

Interstellar brings the laws of physics and puts a spin on it, what is great about this film is that you cant say its possible, but you cant say its not either. It has it's qualities production, effects and performance wise. But as far as plot, especially in terms of pace, ability to surprise you or at least keep you remotely engaged (or anything but confused/ dumbfounded) is where it lets itself down. Plus the big plot twist I could see coming.

I guess as hard as I tried I wanted to like it but I don't think that was the case.

Interstellar it's another great movie made by Christopher Nolan that has everything: Great performances, a solid plot, an unexpected ending, and science theories. The Soundtrack by Hans Zimmer is the best in all 2014. The only problem in the movie is the runtime.

Christopher Nolan has a way of taking the most believable characters and making them say the most unbelievable things. His dialogue plays to exposition through nearly all of this massively pontificated, pretentiously annoying film. While watching his latest attempt at a dramatic epic I could feel the hairs on the back of my neck begin to stand on end, and not in the "wow that was really good" way, but more of a nervous cringe I get when I start to realize a great filmmaker has made an embarrassment of himself. His use of the word "Love" may have come off well in the script, but on screen I wanted to laugh out loud. Nolan is gifted, and one of the few working today that actually is, but he's not impressing me with this one. And I think that's what upsets me the most. I feel he was leaping to impress, and to entertain, but forgot one of the most basic principles of exceptional movie making. 
Having faith in your audience. 
After Hathaway's character began to explain the breakdown of the current scene they were in, and then transition to an overly descriptive explanation of the next scene to come, I almost walked out from feeling so intellectually insulted. I felt like I was inside of a grown up version of Dora the Explorer. Nolan insists on holding the audiences hand the entire way through, and in doing so, misses it's intellectual punches along the way. If only he'd have a touch more faith in us movie goers.
If he begins to write movies a little more for himself, and a little less for the laymen, he will have achieved the depth of his genius and potential. But until then...
Very enjoyable.  Things got a little implausible near the end, but an interesting film nonetheless.  Worth a watch.

Movies that are worth three hours of my time are few and far between. Luckily, this is one of them.  It's an amazing movie.  I saw it in 4K but I can't say that I noticed a marked improvement in the image quality. 

Some of the situations that are presented in the movie are beyond our current knowledge of the universe. They may in fact be unknowable by our species. Yet this movie presents them in an way that allowed me to suspend my disbelief. The director kept me engaged with beautiful and mesmerizing imagery of what these situations and celestial bodies might look like in person.  

The movie is unique because it deals with the fact that time is limited for our species and General Relativity tells us that gravity and relative motion affect time. They both come into play if you try to travel long distances. You lose time with those you leave behind and the time lost in your frame of reference accelerates when you are in a larger gravitational field than earth.  For a space traveller, in most cases, time passes on Earth quicker than it does on your spaceship.  This movie will show you what that means and how that feels.

It's an intense, suspenseful, memorable, terribly sad, and epic drama.  It has a wicked twist to it as well.  One that I didn't see coming.  

I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys smart movies, deep movies, or space movies.
Basically a prequel to Wall-E.

Nolan's vision is a sight to behold but "Interstellar" plots its way into a black hole it doesn't get itself out of.  

"Interstellar" manages to be captivating throughout most of its run but struggles to effectively pay off its immense potential.  But you have to applaud its conceptual ambition.

Admittedly lukewarm on Nolan films (with the exception of Memento), it took me a few weeks to decide to watch this film.  I very much enjoyed the premise and the foundation of the film.  I thought the father/daughter relationship dynamic was well done.  We got a good understanding of McConaughy's character, and I had no problem with NASA's "solution" to the problem.  So far, so good.

I thought the messages back and forth was a good idea - wish they had stuck with that a little better to continue the family connection and better understand how Earth was getting worse and worse, but not a big deal.  The investigation of the first planet was fine, except for Hathaway's idiot character that couldn't see a 1,000 ft wave coming.  But I was still enjoying the film at that point.

Then, came Matt Damon's entry into the movie - and with it, Nolan's biggest flaw reared its ugly head.  Nolan is not great at developing characters or having them make "believable" choices at times.  Matt Damon's character fell right into this trap.  His character was truly pointless.  *SPOILERS AHEAD FROM HERE ON* Was he concerned with humanity?  If so, why signal the beacon?  What was killing McConaughey's character going to accomplish?  Why not just tell McConaughey that Plan A was a lie, and the planet was inhabitable.  It was a waste of a 1/2 hour to be honest.

Then, it felt like Nolan just started making shit up, and eventually painted himself into a corner.  Anybody with a brain knew McConaughey was the "ghost" by the 2nd time little Murph mentioned it.  It was as obvious as Bruce Willis being dead in Sixth Sense - YOU DIDN'T FOOL ANYONE WHO WAS PAYING ATTENTION.  But, to actually, literally, 100% go the deus ex machina route more egregiously then I have ever seen it presented, was lazy and embarrassing in my opinion.  And, Murph being "The Chosen One"?  Yeah - we've never gone THAT route before (Matrix, Avatar, etc).  

Once again, I got sucked into the trap that is Christopher Nolan.  Much like The Dark Knight, the foundation of the movie was well done and intriguing;  but, Nolan's inability to stay the course, develop his characters throughout a movie, and his awkwardness in trying to deliver a sensible ending ruined a potentially very good film.  I believe, in all, this is Nolan's weakest film to date.

Grade = 4.5/10

This film is as close to the spirit of 2001: A Space Odyssey that I have ever seen. The Nolans have done an excellent job of using this medium to communicate a wonderful message about being human and facing the challenges of the future. When we do go out into space we face off against Nature which doesn't care if we survive or not. The good and evil we experience we will bring with us as we spread across the universe. Dr. Mann was an excellent example of the fears and selfishness that hold us back as a species. I thought the cast did a great job with this heavy material that could have easily turned maudlin in lesser hands. Special kudos to Mackenzie Foy who played the young Murphy. The girl has fantastic acting chops and worked well with McConaughey's Cooper. The visual FX were stunning on the IMAX screen complimented by a stunning score from Hans Zimmer. The music becomes a character in moving the narrative forward. I loved it so much I had to buy it and put it on replay on my car stereo. 

SPOILER ALERT!  The highlight of this movie for me was to discover that Nolan didn't have advanced aliens or a god rescue humanity from this disaster. That would have been such a huge letdown so it was very exciting to have the savior of our species be our future selves. This was a positive, life affirming message to leave the audience with as we walk out of the theater. I look forward to the Blu-ray so I can add this film to my personal library.

Interstellar is one of those movies that I watched intently, didn't miss a beat of it, and I was totally engrossed in the whole thing. However, once the experience was over, I wondered why they made it? It's not that Interstellar is a bad movie. The production value is high, the acting works well, and the script . . . well there's the problem. The script just isn't deep or specific enough for me.

The best parts of Interstellar are the scenes between the father and daughter. There's a deep connection there between the characters, a good sense of a specific relationship that is still universal, the love between father and daughter. However, the final scene of that relationship (I won't tell you what it is) is rather dissatisfying.  Also working for this film (for the most part) is the sound. Yes, it's damn loud but it helps create such a visceral response in the audience. Best example: when the spaceship is leaving the Earth there is this bone rattling (I mean, it physically SHOOK the audience) sound of the rocket engines, and then when it finally left the Earth's gravity and entered outer space 

. . . dead quiet. But not wanting to let go of a good thing, they use the same sound level in another part of the movie when the spaceship is in trouble (again), and it only got in the way of the audience hearing important dialogue. I mean, I "think" it was important dialogue because I couldn't understand a word of it, AND in turn, I couldn't understand what was happening in the movie!

Although Christopher Nolan has great ideas and a good eye for visuals, the script seems more of an outline for a movie leaving this audience member feeling a bit underwhelmed. And the "science moments?" Yeah, I know, there's a whole group of scientists out there who get their equations all in a bunch if you don't get the science "right," but every "science moment" they have in Interstellar stops the action, it's not incorporated into the film as well as it needs to be. I ain't kidding. Every time they started talking science I felt like somebody walked on with a giant dry erase board and I was back in junior college sitting through another boring lecture. Don't get me wrong, getting the science  "right" is important but you must make it a part of the action, and not just shove it down our throats because you're afraid  that Dr. deGrasse Tyson will jump on his iPod show and get all "better than thou" on us "uneducated," low life movie goers.

I think it's time for him to get back to basics.

I am a huge fan of Christopher Nolan, he is my favorite director, and Interstellar shows every reason why. From the fantastically spellbinding story to the phenomenal cast, Interstellar delivers on so many levels. Matthew McConaughey has established himself as a true leading man in recent years, and he plays Cooper with so much determination and emotion that really makes you connect with the character and understand him. Anne Hathaway, Jessica Chastain, Casey Affleck, and Michael Caine also are grand in their respective roles. The story and the science behind the film make it interesting right off the bat, its roughly 170 Min yes, but its hardly boring on any level. Nolan has delivered another masterpiece to add to his impressive resume.

Before I begin my review, let me give you some reference about some information on this movie: The Science of Interstellar (book by Kip Thorne), some other YouTube videos that talks about the Science of Interstellar.
The rest of my review will be more about the film's criticism and greatness excluding the scientific ideas through it, because those are on the references I've mentioned earlier. 
So, Interstellar is still a great American science fiction of probably the decade so far. It questions and raises theories and concept that we may or may not heard before in our high school science class that somehow may have also not taught in a university college as well. In terms of filmmaking, Nolan has outdone himself again for being an ambitious talented auteur that is not even mimicking or plagiarizing other directors unlike some if you know who I am talking about. The all-star cast gives us a very memorable and sometimes unforgettable character relationships ever to put on film, spanning more than 50 years on Earth and less than a month on space? Of course, the soundtrack is electrifying and intense, the visual FX is state of the art, and yes don't get me wrong about this, I gotta admit after a few hours just seeing the film, I now have some theories and thoughts about the last 30 minutes of the film which will put some people away if they're not into the film, but for me, I dig it. 
Interstellar, in my own personal opinion without looking at other people's review, is arguably and debatably the most realistic and accurate 100% pure science fiction EVER on the history of cinema. In quite some time, I might put this film on my great movies review maybe not this time. Though with all that saying, I am gonna put Interstellar so far in my #2 on my top 10 movies of 2014 along with Boyhood as my #1. Trust me and believe me on this one, I doubt any more movies I watch in this coming days leading to the last week of 2014 where I reveal my top 10 will never replace Interstellar on my top 2 position. Interstellar must be seen on the biggest screen possible and if you can't or no time, you got to wait for the blu-ray release and see it on your HDTV to truly feel the spectacle of the stellar of space.

Intellectually this is still Nolan-cool-and-superior, but emotionally this might be his most accessible film yet. The scene where Coop views his kids' messages on a viewscreen in a spaceship miles away from Earth is potent stuff. I though the film was a bit too long, with a bit too much "science" justification/exposition, and trying a little too hard to pay homage to 2001 in the final act. I also thought the balance of the scenes in the last five minutes was off - too little payoff for what we'd been waiting for, reunion-wise, too much Hathaway. Yet I found the film mostly to be absorbing, thought-provoking, and often thrilling, in a few sequences - and not just action ones. I loved the stuff where they debated their options. TARS is absolutely fantastic and steals every moment he has. The film resonates with me because I remember a time when kids looked up at the stars and dreamed of exploration, as opposed to now when kids look down at their screens and dream of more data allowance.

Amazing, fully science-based space exploration film! 

Besides finding a habitable planet, the team at NASA was trying to figure out how to get big colonies of people off the Earth. That is why they were trying to "solve" the equation, and why they needed data from inside a black hole. They wanted to explain the gravitational anomalies that were popping up and (hopefully) use them to their advantage. 

Unfortunately, it was too difficult for the filmmakers to get the basic physics across to the audience. I would recommend reading the book "The Science of Interstellar" in order to better appreciate the film.

I have not seen a movie that left me with so much awe in awhile. I read the reviews, and I am absolutely baffled. This movie had so many dimensions, it requires your full attention and it's so rewarding. It explains in theory, how relativity, quantum physics, etc works through space travel but you're not supposed to understand it. The audio was done so you're not supposed to analyze every word or every scene.  Watch the movie with no prejudice, or expectations, and you will appreciate the depth of achievement this movie has accomplished. No movie can compare for the past few years.

While it is entertaining to sit through, Interstellar is a weak attempt at creating a fulfilling plot. In fact, it appears that the writer's goal was simply to implement as many twists as possible. Yes Christopher Nolan may have incorporated some real physics and true facts about outer space phenomena, but that is the only positive. Despite the movie being two and half hours long, the plot needed more time to develop for it to have a chance of reaching greatness. Overall, Interstellar is something that you can sit and watch and follow the mental maze the movie tries to create, but when it is over you will be left with an unsatisfied feeling of "that was it?"

Christopher Nolan has a lot to make up to me after that last Batman movie. I know some people love it, but I was seriously disappointed in it. I also have to admit that I wasn't sure how confident I could feel with Matthew McConaughey as the lead role. Nolan had better come through this time.

I'm happy to report that while it's not as awe-inspiring as his other films, Nolan managed to pull off an incredibly ambitious experience that celebrates technology and the human spirit. Unfortunately the characters are drawn in the broadest of strokes so none of them were very memorable. I had almost completely forgotten that Wes Bentley was in this movie. That being said, McConaughey does his McConaughey thing but somehow makes it work here. Anne Hathaway actually does a good job in delivering a full character, despite what feels like limited screen time. The true reason to see the movie is the spectacle of the visuals, and they're flat out amazing. I will say that there is underlying mystery in the story that almost anyone who watches movies will be able to figure out within 5 minutes. That being said, when the mystery was solved, where the story went afterward was a complete enjoyable surprise for me, and really shocking if you've watched any Christopher Nolan movie before. Just when you think the director might be going full on Hollywood, he delivers an ending that reminds you of exactly who he is.

It does feel a little long, clocking in at close to 3hrs, and I'm still not 100% sure I understand the ending, but I'd definitely go see it again, maybe in full on IMAX to really get all those Nolan visuals in my face.

What can I possibly say to explain Interstellar?  Perhaps I should begin by admitting I did not fully understand this movie, and you probably won't either. Honestly I doubt that Steven Hawking and Neil Tyson Degrassi really understand this movie. That's not because of plot holes or poor exposition but because it is based around concepts which are themselves mind bending. Here time dilation, gravitational anomalies, and supermassive black holes are just the beginning leading up to paradoxes that make Doctor Who seem straightforward and understandings of time and space that we don't yet have the ability to comprehend. In other words there are things in this movie which are not explained because they simply cannot be.
But that matters less than you would think. You'll probably understand the who and the why of the story even if you don't always understand the how. What is important to understand is that the earth is dying. Society is trying to rebuild itself after some unspecified cataclysm, but world population is dangerously low, the farm belt is In the midst of another dust bowl, and though few realize it yet our crops are on the verge of dying. Our only hope is to follow messages from unknown beings to new worlds in another galaxy. And it's going to be one hell of a trip, both for the handful of brave astronauts and the people they leave behind on earth.
	Put simply, Interstellar is 2001 A Space Odyssey without the long stretches where nothing happens. Not to say that the story is the same beyond the general outline of mankind exploring the cosmos and a mysterious force guiding us. Yet there are so many things about Interstellar that draw the viewer's mind back to that classic of sci-fi. From the often majestic, sometimes hallucinatory visuals of alien worlds, interstellar phenomena and spacecraft gently floating through the void, to the ever present themes of distance and isolation, to the black, slab shaped robot with an attitude like HAL 9000, it's clear that Kubrick's 2001 was very much on Christopher Nolan's mind when he made this. 
	But don't let me give you the impression that this move is all high concepts and deep themes. Interstellar is also a fast paced, suspense filled thriller with all the action, twists, and cutting edge special effects one has come to expect from Nolan. The action scenes are nail biting and visually stunning, with photography clearly influenced by last year's Gravity. In the third act the revelations and close calls come so quickly one after another that the tension builds until you're sure the climax is just around the corner, and yet it keeps on going, tenser than before. 

Beyond the suspense and the excitement it's the emotional dimension that gives this movie its impact. Because the heroes aren't going into the unknown just to save humanity, they're going to save the people they care about; their children, parents, mentors, the ones who can't even know if they're still alive. And as corny as it may seem, Interstellar makes a good case that more than gravity or even time, it's love that's the most powerful force in the galaxy. In the end you'll likely have as many questions as answers, but that's OK, because the whole point is that there is so much we have yet to discover, and yet that will never stop us from trying.

Interstellar isn't necessarily a landmark in storytelling or cinematic razzle-dazzle. A few of the characters fall flat, some of the dialogue is poorly written, and so forth. But even for a science-fiction film, it breaks past archetypal themes and forces the audience to expand their imagination. Few films have managed to capture the spirit of discovery quite like this.

Furthermore, while it is first and foremost science-*fiction*, Interstellar exposes its viewers to some very real scientific concepts which can expand their understanding of the world outside the theater and everyday life. It's the kind of film that you might need to read over or have explained to you - except, unlike Inception, the most mind-boggling bits are very much real parts of our universe.
