Not a bad movie if you don't think about it.  I thought about it and have some issues with it:

Cooper drives a truck at high speed on roads and corn fields on a flat tire which never disintegrates or becomes more damaged in any way.

Cooper takes control of a military grade drone with a laptop and high gain antenna, which he just happens to have with him along with the necessary encryption codes and frequencies (which constantly change using "Spread Spectrum") and land the drone even though it flies some distance away without the high gain antenna pointed at it making it out of range for a simple laptop wireless.   

The drone is powered by solar panels which will provide enough power to run a farm.  Apparently we solved the energy crisis just in time for the food crisis. 

All the automated farm equipment descend on the house but stop just short of doing any damage.  One massive harvester is seen lumbering through the corn field with out doing any damage to the corn.

Dust storms block out all visibility but never enter the car vents or clog the air filter even though it's being sucked into the engine at 300 cubic feet per minute.

Dust falls on the floor in lines about one inch apart.  Cooper recognizes the pattern as binary code and realizes they represents coordinates (latitude/longitude) but needs to work out the location on paper because even though he can recognize them on site he can't read them.

Latitude and longitude in binary looks like this:
 01001110 00100000 00110100 00110101 00111010 00110001 00110101 00111010 00110010 00110010 00100000 01010111 00100000 00110001 00110000 00110010 00111010 00110100 00110101 00111010 00110001 00110110 
there's not nearly enough floor space.

We learn that the world wide food shortage has ended all wars.  Really?  People riot for injustice but roll over for no food!

Cooper and his dad often drink beer on the porch at night.  If corn is the only grain that can grow on the planet where does the beer com from?

Cooper is chosen to pilot the ENDEAVOR because he's the only one with experience as no one else has made it beyond the simulator.  So how did they get the ENDEAVOR up there in the first place?  How did the original 12 astronauts make it?

NASA is now a super secret organization because people would be opposed to the government spending money on space exploration when people are starving.  So how did they get that spaceship up there without anyone seeing all those components being launched?  And even though the International Space Station is clearly visible from Earth no one notices this massive space ship in orbit?

Professor Brand is the only one working on the gravity calculations on which the fate of the world hangs.  There are a number of "Self aware" computers walking around but no computer resources are dedicated to solving this problem.  Later he tutors a 10 year old who grows up to finish the equation, but seriously; shouldn't have they given this a little more priority?

The RANGER lander has the ability to land on planets and take off again to return on it's own, so why did thy need to put it on the top of a rocket to get it to the ENDEAVOR when they left Earth?

Plan "A" is to move the human race to the other side of the wormhole to a new planet.  Plan "B" is to repopulate the human race on a distant planet using fertilized embryos.  Where did they get all those embryos from without people noticing?  Wouldn't this require women on the other end to be implanted without the aid of a medical facility?  Doesn't the success of plan "B" necessitate the success of plan "A"? Doesn't that make Brand one REALLY popular woman?

When free floating in the spaceship Brand is seen floating toward the ceiling then changing direction without touching anything.

When landing on the Miller planet they discuss how gravity and time are related with time moving slower with higher gravity.  While they get kudos for tackling the subject, 130% of Earth gravity is no where near enough to dilate time on the order of 1 hour to 7 years.  A ratio of 1:61320.   The time shift would have slowed down the rate of data transmission so much that 10 minutes worth of data would have taken just over a year of recording time on Earth before they knew what they had.  Also dilation effects radio waves differently then it does time.  It changes the frequency, in this case drastically.  So Earth would not know what they were listening to nor would they know where to look for it. 

Planet Miller has huge slow moving  waves but no moon to cause them.  Is the gravitational pull of the black hole strong enough to create large title waves but leave the rest of the planet intact? Did no one think to bring binoculars to look at the planet from space and notice "Hey, it's nothing but water!  We better not land there."

 Was Miller a moron?  Did he really think that landing on an all water planet with huge waves so close to a black hole was a GOOD idea?

Brand wants to go to the third planet because that's where her boyfriend is.  A character never introduced or plot line ever developed but somehow Cooper figures it out anyway.

Communication is possible from Earth through the wormhole to the other side and even though Earth has been receiving environmental data from planetary sensors from the other side of the wormhole communication from the ENDEAVOR to Earth is impossible.    

Cooper receives a message from his son who tells him he wanted to name the first grandchild Coop but it was a girl.  We later find he had a son that he named Coop.  So Cooper has a grandson named Cooper Cooper.

When on Mann's planet they get around with the help jet packs attached to their forearms by holding their arm perpendicular to their bodies with their forearms raised in the typical "Strong man" pose and holding them in this position while lifting their entire weight off the planet.  Something I've only seen Olympic athletes do.

Mann is a man who is insane is an allegory for man that is insane which is the back story for the movie.

The computers on the ENDEAVOR will risk their existence because they have to do what their told but ignore Mann who repeatedly tells them to auto dock. 

Professor Brand confesses the gravity equation can't be solved without going into a black hole which can't be done which we all know will happen next.

While in the black hole the beings that created the wormhole construct a tesseract so that Cooper can explore the past days of Murphy's childhood so he can communicate with Murphy, give the answer to the gravity equation thus utilizing the worn out "Time paradox" without which the movie (and all mankind) wouldn't exist.

So the amazingly intelligent beings, seeing mankind on the brink of extinction, construct a wormhole near Saturn that leads to a black hole near 12 planets, only one of which can support life, and construct a tesseract inside the black hole so ONE man can look into his past and give the binary form of the gravity equation solution onto a watch that will be discovered by his daughter many years later who will solve the equation allowing mankind to leave earth in space stations using the same contaminated soil that's destroying all the food but somehow has no effect in space.  Sure, why not?  Why did they put the wormhole all the way out near Saturn?  I mean they can reach into a black hole, construct a time paradoxical tesseract so we can give ourselves the key to our survival, why didn't they just dial 911 or something?  Or put an intergalactic doorway on earth that pops out on the good planet?  Why not put a flashing neon sign that says "Good planet this way."?  I'm beginning to  think these beings DON'T have our best interest in mind and are just screwing with us.  Maybe THEY'RE the reason the Earth is dying to begin with. 

Murphy is seen transcribing the binary equation from the watch into Morse code, a form of communication that has no provision for higher math functions.

After solving the gravity equation Murphy then takes decades of hard work and throws it all in the air leaving someone else to pick up the mess, put all the paper back in order and figure out just what the heck she's yelling about. 

After giving the equation, Cooper ends up back in the Solar system in the path of a rescue vehicle proving the Beings could have easily moved mankind off earth to the good planet whenever they wanted.

Cooper wakes up back on Cooper station and egotistically thinks it's named after  him.  Apparently nothing was named after him.  Maybe he should have tried harder.

Cooper's daughter insists on seeing him even though she's too old to go to him and apparently was in suspended animation at the time she was told.  

Brand land's on her lovers planet despite having no experience piloting a severely damaged spaceship that's being torn apart all the way there, and find's the remains of her lover over 100 years too late and even though being exposed to the elements still finds enough to bury.  Mann survived just fine in the suspended animation unit but he can't?

Cooper decides to risk his life by going back through the worm hole to live out his remaining years all alone with Brand, a woman who gave him no encouragement, instead of using his fame and notoriety to get any hot babe he wished.  

Apparently it's really easy to steal spacecraft in the future.  No guards, alarms, sensors, cameras, radar or anything else that would make someone say "Hey, what's he doing?"

Despite being 100 years more advanced, flight control systems of spacecraft have not changed since Cooper's day.  Something akin to the Wright brothers being able to fly a 747.
Probablemente de las mejores peliculas de ciencia ficcion que pude ver.

A breathtaking and mind-blowing film that manages to take you on an emotional ride along with stunning visuals.  Things are wrapped up with a bow on them so to speak in the end but this can be forgiven as without this the starkness and harshness of space travel would make the film more brutal than inspirational.  This is one to see on IMAX.

I wish I could go through a blackhole and tell myself to s-t-a-y away. I love sci-fi and Christopher Nolan. I don't like being a critic. But the movie was laugh out loud bad and I can't understand how the reviews have been so positive.  There is probably an amazing 2 hour movie trapped inside the 5th dimension of this 168 min odyssey. Love of this film does not transcend space and time.

Visually stunning and armed with an impeccable cast, Interstellar starts out as thought-provoking and intriguing - unfortunatly the film looses that pace somewhere in the last third of its durance, where it suddenly becomes disappointingly cheesy. I think those who saw it might know what sequence I'm talking about. The ending however saves most of that slip. Overall, it was a wild ride from beginning to end.

Like all Nolan films, Interstellar is ambitious, visually-stunning, emotional, well scored, well acted, well scripted, and thought-provoking, but as Interstellar reaches its end, the plot becomes overall confusing & dissatisfying.
Melodramatic nonsense dressed up with loud, over the top special effects and tired, ridiculous cliches.  A long movie that just felt long ....
